name: DutchAUG @ droidconNL
description:
"Acte de presence"

We, the DutchAUG organizers, will be attending droidconNL. As a matter of fact that's where we will officially announce this group and hopefully find some enthusiastic new members. Are you going as well? Let everybody know by RSVPing and we will have a short meetup at the BBQ on Tuesday the 22nd.

Help us spread the word!

If you are as thrilled about this group as we are (or maybe a little less, that's fine as well) you can help us spread the word at droidconNL. Or, if you prefer, you can achieve this non-verbally by wearing our t-shirt (in red, white or blue).

Front

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Back

name: Theme Thursday: "From idea to app"
description:
Theme Thursday: "From idea to app"

On our very first DutchAUG meetup we will dive right into the Android internals by presenting you a mini conference with the theme "From idea to app".

We will start the meetup with a session about concept and (interaction) design, followed by dinner. We will continue with best practices about developing and testing your app. After a short break we will conclude the evening with a session about how you can make your app visible on the market and getting it out there. When the sessions are over the barcamp starts and you can grab a drink.

Schedule:

16:30 - 17:00 Walk-in 17:00 - 17:10 Opening and welcome 17:10 - 17:20 General announcements DutchAUG 17:20 - 18:00 "From concept to design" (Bram Braat) 18:00 - 19:00 Dinner 19:00 - 19:40 "Android app development" (Hugo Visser) 19:40 - 20:00 Coffee break 20:00 - 20:40 "Publish, Promote and Improve your app" (Dante Eckhardt) 20:40 - 21:30 "Barcamp" (YOU! The rest, by all means grab a drink with that ;-)

Bram Braat
Bram has a background in industrial design and is specialized in the field of interaction between user and product (or system). He's able to determine the demands and wishes of the intended users and designs products and interfaces by means of user testing systems. To this purpose he often uses fast, but highly interactive prototypes. This, to allow for the user to experience working with the real system. By means of the constructed prototype a visual design is then created for the final target platform.

Follow Bram Braat on Twitter or Google+

Hugo Visser
Hugo is best known for his "Rainy Days" app. A 4,4 star weather app with nearly 500K downloads! Hugo will share with us his experience and vision on what good Android development and testing is all about. He is passionate about Android and is never afraid to share his opinion on the ever ongoing Android vs iPhone and Native vs Cross-platform development discussions. Hugo has a strong background in software development, system integration and optimization of development processes. At Qbus he is responsible for all things technical with a special focus on mobile solutions and Android in particular. On the mobile side he has developed for JavaME and Windows Mobile, but found his true love in Android. When Hugo isn't working on Rainy Days or tinkering with Android otherwise, he enjoys spinning a few (vinyl!) records as a home-DJ.

Follow Hugo on Twitter or Google+

Dante Eckhardt
Dante is the creator of the "Super Deals Nederland" app, a 4,3 star app which has reached the 50K download mark this November (congratulations on that Dante!). Dante is a Senior Consultant in the Microsoft division at Capgemini and is currently active in a senior developer role at Philips. Dante has been working with the .Net-Framework professionally for the last couple of years, but for the past year he has freely, and with pleasure, given up a lot of his spare time to work with the Android framework. If there is any spare time left Dante likes to kick a soccer ball or two.

Barcamp
If you have anything interesting you would like to share with the group, this is your chance! You can think about asking the group about a best practice for a programming challenge you are facing, or start a fuss by taking a stand on e.g. the cross-platform debate, maybe a great moment to demo your app or app concept, get some feedback and maybe solicit some partners in crime, etc. Barcamp slots will be max 5 minutes per person, to give a larger group a chance to present something. If you already have a topic and have some slides please send them to [masked] and we'll make sure they are on the laptop connected to the beamer.

During the barcamp we will have some drinks and time to meet and speak with each other. Of course we will do our very best to include some giveaways and goodies. Dinner and drinks will be sponsored by VX Company.

Regards

Wiebe, Arno, Dennis, Hilbrand and Johan
how_to_find_us: The conference will be held in the basement of the building. You will be guided by signs and friendly people.

name: Creatieve sessie voor medische Android applicaties
description: Binnen het st. Antoniusziekenhuis wordt door zo'n bijna 20 ontwikkelaars gewerkt aan de interne medische applicaties. Deze zijn nu voornamelijk webgebaseerd maar we werken ook al aan Android telefoon en tablet applicaties. We organiseren een creatieve sessie om zo van elkaar te leren wat het beste is in een aantal situaties. Wil je met ons meedenken tijdens een pizza? Meld je dan aan! Aantal deelnemers is nl beperkt. De agenda in grote lijnen: 17:00 ontvangst 17:30 pizza 18:00 demo van ons intern ontwikkelde EPD (mag uitlopen als er veel vragen zijn) 18:15 discussie en uitwisseling van ideeen

name: DutchAUG @ Global Android Dev Camp
description:
Introduction

There's a Global Android Dev Camp in Brussels next weekend. Read on below. This only makes sense for developers, designers or UX experts that know a bit of Android.

Disclaimer: BruGTUG organizes the Brussels event, and it's too short to host a matching event in Holland at this time, which is unfortunate but understandable. In this way we'd like to welcome those of you who'd prefer to really be part of it (even one day only). For anyone else, know that you will be able to join in via Google+ Hangouts: http://gplus.to/gadcbru .

The details

On the weekend of February 18th and 19th there is an Android hackathon in Brussels, organized by the BruGTUG. This coincides with a Global Android Dev Camp happening the same weekend over Google+ Hangouts. Android developers from all over the world come together at more than 50 locations and write app code - nonstop! Globally, about 1,000 developers are expected - from Brussels to Berlin, to Warsaw and London, to Brazzaville, Kyoto and San Diego.

Learn about hands-on Android app development The event will include a beginner-level jumpstart session on the major features of Android, focused on 4.0 development, Fragments, and releasing to the Market. Android enthusiasts will be on hand to help and to answer questions throughout the weekend.  Build with Us or Build Your Own Throughout the weekend, other GTUG members, locally or globally, will be building Android apps and sharing the code with you so you can code along. If, on the other hand, you already have a great idea for what to build, bring that idea with you to the hackathon, pitch it in the morning and form a team. Even better, bring along anything you can prepare ahead of time (sketches, designs, mockups, an empty template app etc.) and use the time, information and talented people provided at the hackathon to develop your idea into a working application. At the end of the day, we'll invite you to share your Android app with the world.  What Do I Need? We will provide facilities and experts to help you learn to use Android and write your application. Just bring your laptop, ideas, absolute concentration and enthusiasm to complete the mix.  When? The Brussels hackathon will take place Saturday and Sunday, February 18th and 19th, from 10:00(am) to 03:00(am) on Saturday, and from 09:00(am) to 08:00(pm) on Sunday. The location will not allow us to stay the night, so this will not be required or provided, but you are free to continue your work overnight at your own location. The deadline to finish your hack is Sunday 18:00.  Where? It will be held at Outpost GameCenter, Rue de la Tribune 8, Brussel: This location is accessible via train or metro via Central Station or Madou, and some limited street parking should be possible for cars. This is the last chance to sign up You may also want to circle the BruGTUG G+ page.

Lastly, please actively spread the news, tell your friends, and create a social media storm using #GADC. Thanks for your support. Together we can create amazing things!

 

Regards Pieter-Jan

name: Android meets the Enterprise
description:
Introduction

Software companies are most likely working on many Android apps. There is an increased need want to control this development process. That means a lean process with automated tests and builds, re-usable components and the right amount of security.

In this meetup we want to address these Enterprise challenges.

Preliminary schedule:

16:30 - 17:00 Walk-in 17:00 - 17:10 Opening and welcome (Atos) 17:10 - 17:20 General announcements (DutchAUG) 17:20 - 18:00 "The Android Software Lifecycle Management Process" (Mylène Reiners) 18:00 - 19:00 Dinner 19:00 - 19:40 "Securely Storing Secrets on Android devices" (Ivo Jansch)  19:40 - 20:00 Coffee break 20:00 - 20:40 "Reinventing data storage and synchronization" (Wouter Vegter) 20:40 - 21:30 Barcamp The Android Software Lifecycle Management Process

Lots of people are writing Android apps. Some of them write apps, that are to be used by enterprises – both employees and customers. Often those apps are in one way or another connected to enterprise systems, and need to find their place in the whole enterprise application/software landscape. This is no easy task.

All of a sudden us, builders of fun apps, need to comply with standards, need to use version control, continuous integration and the like. Our apps are tested by people who do not only look at the “wow” factor, but who thoroughly look at functionality – and whether the app is built in accordance with the requirements… Our apps need to comply with lots of –ilities (availability, maintainability, reliability, testability etc.).People from the operations team want to be able to exactly know what influence the app will have on diverse resources. All of a sudden building apps has become work…

In my presentation I would like to address some of the aforementioned topics, especially where the process differs from the “traditional” software lifecycle management process. This traditional process will be described shortly, to give the audience the necessary context. Then I will zoom in on the differences between traditional SLMP and Android SLMP. First (shortly) on requirements – especially what is special about apps, on architecture and development (main focus), and why you need standardization, quality, security etc., but also the tools to use. After that (again shortly) testing, administration, maintenance etc.

This is not meant to be a static presentation, but – when the allotted time slot allows it – there will be a demonstration of how this whole process (as far as tooling is concerned) could work, and why we chose this tooling etc.

Mylène Reiners

http://photos3.meetupstatic.com/photos/event/2/b/4/event_83880692.jpegMylène has been employed in the field of ICT since 1988, and gained experience in lots of technologies and roles. Currently she works at Atos Nederland B.V. in Eindhoven, and spends almost all of her time working as a software architect and as Dutch competence lead for Java EE and Android. Besides that, her interest is centered around software quality and software security, software craftsmanship and agile, SaaS and Open Source and Open Standards. She tries to keep up-to-date with all of those interests, mostly conceptual, sometimes by going hands-on.

 

 

 

Securely Storing Secrets on Android Devices

Services such as Twitter use OAuth to allow their users to grant us - the developers of apps - access to their resources. We in turn use twitter or other identity providers for authenticating our users and give them access to our own APIs. This triangular relationship requires trust between everybody involved.

While in theory this is great, in practice we run into a lot of issues. Many developers store their consumer secrets inside an app, basically placing the keys to the kingdom in user's hands and trust the Android security model to protect these keys. The alternatives, ranging from dynamically exchanging token secrets to building custom proxies can be complicated, especially for app developers that just want to focus on the app, without having to worry about custom backend APIs.

In this talk, we will look at the security implications of the app, API and third party services love triangle and look at ways to improve security without compromising usability. The talk mixes theory with practical examples.

Ivo Jansch

http://photos2.meetupstatic.com/photos/event/8/2/7/a/event_90333402.jpegIvo Jansch is one of the founders of Egeniq.com, a mobile technology company based in Utrecht. He is one of the architects and developers of the Tiqr authentication application for Android and iPhone. Ivo focuses on software architecture and best practices in mobile app development. He has authored 2 books and is a regular speaker at conferences (previous presentations and books can be found on http://www.jansch.nl)

 

 

Reinventing data storage and synchronization

Android is enterprise-wise still very immature. Although demands for data handling are growing at a very fast rate, we are still left with basic database access and ill defined classes for data synchronisation. Based on significant Android enterprise experience, combined with insight of other software frameworks, we are building an enterprise ORM and synchronisation framework. We tried to follow the Android architecture guidelines as strict as possible, while leaving space for generic streamlined functionality.This session will discuss the challenges we encountered during our enterprise app development and will touch upon some key functionalities needed for a steady enterprise Android framework. 
While this is primarily a tech-talk, light is also shed on more practical concepts like out-of-market app distribution, crash reporting and our own general experiences.
The main goal of this session is sharing experiences and sufficiently elegantly working solutions.

 

Wouter Vegter

http://photos2.meetupstatic.com/photos/event/8/1/6/c/event_90333132.jpegWouter Vegter, Android consultant and developer, is working with Android since 2009 with his company Moop.me. Moop.me has developed and designed apps for amongst others Booking.com, PayPal, RodeKruis, Gemeentelijk VervoersBedrijf Amsterdam, but also for enterprise customers like Vebego, NS en Gemeente Rotterdam. Moop.me has won several prices, like the Google developers challenge for Android and the Chrome webstore competition. Wouter is the author of the DevTutorials: the Dutch extensive Android tutorials published on Androidworld.nl. Wouter regurarly gives presentations about Android, from both a technical and a business perspective. Some of Moop.me's own projects include an Android enterprise framework and an iPad cash register solution for small restaurants.

Barcamp
If you have anything interesting you would like to share with the group, this is your chance! You can think about asking the group about a best practice for a programming challenge you are facing, or start a fuss by taking a stand on e.g. the cross-platform debate, maybe a great moment to demo your app or app concept, get some feedback and maybe solicit some partners in crime, etc. Barcamp slots will be max 5 minutes per person, to give a larger group a chance to present something. If you already have a topic and have some slides please send them to [masked] and we'll make sure they are on the laptop connected to the beamer.

During the barcamp we will have some drinks and time to meet and speak with each other. Of course we will do our very best to include some giveaways and goodies. Dinner and drinks will be sponsored by Atos.

Regards

Wiebe, Arno, Dennis, Hilbrand and Johan
how_to_find_us: The reception desk is at the ground floor of building Quarters - you will have to ask for a visitor badge, and wait for someone to guide you to the Lunettenzaal.

name: DutchAUG @ mdevcon
description:
mdevcon 2012

On Saturday March 10th 2012 mdevcon will be held in the beautiful Tuschinski theater in Amsterdam (visit the website to get tickets).

mdevcon is a conference by developers, for developers working with mobile technology. There will be talks targeted at a specific platform and talks of a more platform independent nature. mdevcon welcomes independent developers, freelancers and developers working for a company: "It doesn’t matter who you are or where you work, if you work with mobile technology you’ll enjoy this conference".

Read more about the conference and schedule here. mdevcon is sponsored by Egeniq and organized by DutchAUGer Ivo Jansch.

DutchAUG @ events

As mentioned on the first meetup we are planning to attend a fair amount of mobile conferences ourselves. And with our own organizer Wiebe Elsinga talking on "Prototype your mobile applications" and DutchAUGer Hugo Visser on "Embracing Android Fragmentation" it is a great opportunity to spread the word about the DutchAUG to the mdevcon audience.

If you are attending mdevcon as well let us know by RSVPing "Yes" to this meetup and we'll have a short meetup at one of the conference breaks or sessions.

If you are thinking about attending mdevcon think fast, tickets sales are going fast so decide quickly if you don't want to miss out. If you attend the "Android meets the Enterprise" meetup you have a chance of winning a free ticket, or get your money back (in case you've already bought a ticket), with the compliments of the mdevcon organization.

name: Android Tablet Development
description:
Introduction

Designing and developing for an Android tablet is very different to designing and developing for smartphones. Tablets allow us to exercise our primal urge to move things around with our hands. They are predominantly used at home in the evenings and it's likely that you will be focused on a particular task. This differs from smart phones where we often have lots going on at once and dip in and out of apps as we go. This meetup will provide a look into the development of Android Tablets.

Schedule

• 16:30 - 17:00 Walk-in
• 17:00 - 17:10 Opening and welcome
• 17:10 - 17:20 General announcements
• 17:20 - 18:00 “Designing for Android Tablet” (Wiebe Elsinga)
• 18:00 - 19:00 Dinner
• 19:00 - 19:40 “Coding the Tablet” (Coen Houtman)
• 19:40 - 20:00 Coffee break
• 20:00 - 20:40 “Live demo: how to connect your fragments to cloud-based REST services” (Dennis Geurts)
• 20:40 - 21:30 "Barcamp"

  Wiebe Elsinga

http://photos3.meetupstatic.com/photos/event/4/5/4/e/event_94157742.jpegIs currently a Technical Lead at the mobile department of Itude. He has a long time experience in software development of mobile, web and enterprise applications. He is mainly focused on the development of mobile applications, and is continuously seeking quality improvements within the development process of mobile applications. Besides being a co-organizer of the Dutch Android Usergroup he is also a public speaker at technical conferences worldwide.

Coen Houtman

http://photos4.meetupstatic.com/photos/event/4/4/e/0/event_94157632.jpegStarted his study “computer science” in 2004 to become a software engineer. During his study he was able to gain experience with a variety of programming languages, including: C, C++ and C#. Most classes, however, were built around Java. In 2008 he started working at Itude, where soon after, he joined the mobile department. After working on various mobile projects, he started out on his first Android project in 2010. Since then, he helped building complex Android applications for both smartphones and tablets. In fact, he was responsible for redesigning smartphone applications to make them suitable for tablets.

Dennis Geurts

http://photos2.meetupstatic.com/photos/event/4/5/0/8/event_94157672.jpegIs an experienced software engineer at Luminis. He loves programming for mobile devices (mostly Android, but also for iPhone/iPad) but is also well-versed in OSGi and Java in general. He's also interested in node.js and noSQL (CouchDB and Redis are his favorites).

name: Tools for Android Game Development
description:
On March 24, Raul Portales of The Pill Tree will present a hands-on session on tools you can use for Android game development. This meetup is a co-organization between Appsterdam and the Dutch Android User Group.

When thinking about building a game for Android, one can write it from scratch. Or you can look for tools, libraries and engines that already exist so you don't have to reinvent the wheel. 
 We did that at The Pill Tree for both Chalk Ball and Space Cat, both games have different requirements and the solutions we found were also different. In this session I will summarize the strong and weak points of AndEngine and jPCT-AE and the uses you can make of them. 
 I will also give a brief explanation of other libraries that are interesting, such as ScoreLoop / OpenFeint for scores and awards and give a short introduction to virtual currency and incentivated ads. 
 After the talk, I will provide the people with the samples of both engines and we will play around with them. The event is at the fabulous Mediamatic Bank location, and best of all we'll round off the afternoon with Pizza and Beer.

Agenda

9:30 - 10:00 - Doors open, developers gather, coffee, environment check

10:00 - 12:00 - Getting started: Presentations and exploration of Android game development tools

12:00 - 17:00 - Lunch, "Hackathon" style guided learning with a team

17:00 - Pizza and beer!

This session is targeted at Android developers. Basic knowledge of Android development is required, knowledge of 2D / 3D engine a plus, but not necessary. 

 You will need to bring a laptop with the following software installed and ready: Java 7 SE JDK, Eclipse IDE for Java Developers, Android SDK release 13, and the ADT Plugin for Eclipse. Whew! Here's a pretty good guide if you get lost.

We ask a €25 registration fee (20 if you have a Mediamatic membership) to cover expenses and food. Space is limited to 30 people (15 DutchAUGers and 15 Appsterdammers), so please notify us if you need to cancel before the session. 

Speaker's Bio

http://photos3.meetupstatic.com/photos/event/9/e/d/6/event_91960662.jpegRaul is a Spanish Software Engineer who started writing MSX programs for fun when he was 12 and he still enjoys his development role today. Raul has been working in the IT industry since 2004, but is focused on mobile development since 2006. That includes Windows Mobile, Symbian, Android and iPhone. Android is by far his favorite. He has worked at Hyves, Layar and -of course- The Pill Tree, an Android gaming company based in Amsterdam, where he develops Android games. Raul has several hobbies including Juggling and playing Magic, which explains his personal projects on Android Market.

name: Android Workshop for Beginners
description:
Hi there,

We are happy to announce an Android Workshop for Beginners. Beginners in Android that is. You need an intermediate level in Java or general Object Oriented (OO) programming to get the most out of this workshop. Don't be afraid to join if you are lacking in this area, we'll help you out before or during the workshop.

We will begin with a general presentation on Android architecture and key concepts. Then it's up to you to walk through a series of four labs (on your own laptop) to reach the goal of creating a complete Android app. There will be a couple of experienced Android developers walking around to answer your questions or help you out when you get stuck. We will give you some hints and tips on useful Android tools and you'll get the change to win a copy of "Professional Android 2 Application Development" by Reto Meier, or one of two e-books by Manning and other swag.

The meetup charge of €15 is purely for coffee / thee, drinks, snacks and dinner (which will be sandwiches or pizza or some other simple dinner).

The schedule:

16.00: Walk-in with coffee / thee, drinks and snacks.
16.30: Presentation Android architecture and key concepts

17:00: Workshop lab1 & lab2
18.00: Dinner break

19.00: Workshop lab3 & lab4
20.30: Drinks & snacks

21:00: End

Prerequisites (important!)

To be prepared you need to install the following software and execute the Android Lab primer. This to simply test your Android development environment and because we cannot guarantee we have a good Wifi connection at the workshop location (and downloads can be several hundreds of megabytes). If you have any trouble or questions on any of the installations below let me know and we'll work it out together.

Java Development Kit (JDK) 6 (download)

You can develop Android apps in a couple of languages, but for most apps Java is the preferred language. You need a Java Development Kit (JDK) to develop Android apps. A Java Runtime Environment (JRE) is not sufficient.

Android Software Development Kit (Android SDK) - release 18 (download and install)

The Android Software Development Kit (SDK) is the base kit you need to be able to be able to build and package Android apps. Apart from the Android Framework (where you build your Android app against) the SDK provides you with a lot of tooling to run and test your app on your development system. For instance the SDK comes with an Android emulator which you can use to emulate all kinds of hardware. For the workshop you need to configure at least one Android Virtual Device (AVD), as these emulated devices are called, or you can simply develop apps on your own Android smartphone or tablet (and please, do bring them along!).

After downloading the Android SDK it is important that you at least install 1 Android platform (seestep 4 of the installation instructions). For the workshop we use the latest platform (Ice Cream Sandwich, version 4.0.3) and maybe an old smartphone version (2.3.3) just in case, but the app should run fine on any platform, since we will be using the very basic stuff. Tip, also install the platform-tools, documentation, samples and the source code. These will come in handy when you want to know how Google has solved things in the framework itself.

Eclipse 3.6 (Helios) or 3.7 (Indigo) (download)

Eclipse is the Integrated Development Environment (IDE) which is best suited for Android development, and which we will be using for the workshop. Simply download the latest (3.7.2 a.k.a. Indigo) Eclipse IDE for Java Developers and you are all set.

Eclipse Android Development Tools (ADT) plugin - release 18 (download and install)

This is a plugin for Eclipse which basically makes the Android tools from the Android SDK available in Eclipse and makes your job as Android developer a lot easier. We will spend some time on the tools available in the ADT plugin in the first exercise.

Test your setup

Finally we want to ask you to create a simple "Hello, world" Android project in Eclipse to test your setup. You can use the Android Lab primer, which is a shorter (and hopefully easier) write up of theHello, World exercise by Google, but both should do the job. If you have a running "Hello, world" app you are all set for next week!

Final notes

The Android Workshop is aimed at intermediate Java developers with little to no Android knowledge. If you are lacking Java or general OO programming skills this workshop will be a real challenge. We still think it will give you a jump start if you really want to start Android development. A couple of experienced Android developers will be walking around if you have any questions during the workshop. The workshop fee is €15,- euros. This basically boils down to €5,- for coffee / tea, other drinks and snacks (which we'll buy up front). The other €10,- is for your own pizza / pasta or chinese dish (we'll decide what to eat at the workshop). So if you fancy super-large-extra-toppings-pan-pizza's costing €25 euros please bring along some extra cash. Please bring all your Android devices, books and other cool stuff you would like to show off or use during the workshop. And if you won't be using them maybe your workshop neighbor is interested in using them during the workshop. We have a couple of people on the waiting list. If you already know you can't come please RSVP "No" so others can come in your stead. This workshop is part of the Appril initiative. Hope to see you in Appril!

Johan Pelgrim

P.S. Yes, this is the same workshop as I've given several time last year at VX Company, so feel free to attend again, but you probably won't learn anything new ;-)

name: Dutch Android Open Space
description:
Introduction

If you are familiar with Open Space meetups you know how valuable these type of meetups can be. It is very open, highly active and interactive. Always aiming to discuss, distill and find solutions for the most interesting topics, information and challenges which you are facing every day, in your role as Android professional. This could very well be the most interesting meetup yet, so join sooner rather than later!

Theme: "Together we can build awesome apps!"

If you are working on mobile projects you know that time-to-market is often short. The client wants to have the best looking app and your end-users deserve the best user experience. How do you create an awesome Android app in such a short time frame and still keep smiling? How can we work together? What have you learned along the way and what is still a big hurdle to take, every time you start an Android project? Do you re-use components? And how do you build, test and deploy your app? All fair questions and hopefully disclosing the Open Space theme before the meetup will get you more excited to join the conversation.

Skills in our group...

All kind of roles and skills are represented in our group. From entrepreneurs to testers, graphics designers to architects and of course a fair amount of developers. We need each other to build better apps and this need is clearer than ever in our every day challenge to meet the deadline on some Android project and creating awesome user experiences while we are at it.

Rich Hyndmann opening keynote

http://photos3.meetupstatic.com/photos/event/d/9/8/c/event_118255692.jpegWe are very excited to announce that no one less than Google Android Developer Advocate and DutchAUG supporter Rich Hyndmann will open the Open Space meetup via an On Air hangout. In an inspirational keynote Rich will share his vision on how we can build awesome apps. After his keynote we will open up the hangout for Q&A, so feel free to prepare a question or two for Rich.

Process

We open the doors around 4:30pm and aim to start at 5pm with the opening, welcome, general announcement. After that we will explain the chosen Open Space process:

We will have a large bord with empty time slots. Everybody will have a chance to write down a topic of interest in one of these time slots. (Of course, nothing holds you back to already think about or even prepare a topic you would like to see discussed). If we have more topics then time slots we will either open an extra breakout room, or simply vote on which topics we want to cover. After that we breakout in 30 minute sessions to discuss the top-voted topics. One person, per group, is asked to present what was discussed and possibly some answers, best practices or results. We repeat the breakout / plenary presentation bit two or three times.

Schedule

16:30 Walk-in 17:00 Opening and welcome 17:10 Keynote + Q&A (Rich Hyndmann) 17:30 Start Open Space 17:45 First Breakout Round 18:30 Dinner 19:30 Second Breakout Round 20:15 Third Breakout Round 21:00 Drinks and time to meet. We hope to see a lot of familiar but also new faces at this meetup, so if you have never come to a DutchAUG meetup before, now is a good time ;-)

Kind regards,

 

Wiebe, Dennis, Arno, Hilbrand and Johan.

name: DutchAUG @ Google I/O 2012
description:
The lucky ones...

Google I/O 2012. Three days packed with Google Technology and hopefully a lot of Android session. Can you count yourself amongst the lucky ones holding a ticket to this popular conference? (All tickets were sold out in 20 minutes this year in one big lotery).

Let everybody know you will be in San Francisco by RSVP-ing "Yes" and we'll meetup somewhere for dinner or drinks. If you have any other suggestions or tips let everybody know by commenting on this meetup announcement.

Staying at home...

For those of you staying at home we co-organize a Google I/O Extended viewing party, at the Google office in Amsterdam. This basically is a Google I/O Live viewing party which still gives you the possibility to discuss new technologies and announcements with your fellow Dutchaugers.

name: "V Hack Android" Netherlands
description:
Android 5 years!

On November 5th Android will celebrate its 5th birthday. To celebrate this Google developer- and technology user group leaders in Europe have announced the "V Hack Android" hackathon (pronounced "We Hack Android". If you would like to keep up to date circle their "V Hack Android" Google+ page. While you're at it circle our event's Google+ page as well ;-).

"V Hack Android" Dutch edition

We are happy to announce that together with with the Google Developer Group Netherlands and Appsterdam.rs we will organize the Dutch edition of this international hackathon where teams of exactly 3 people (2 Android developers and 1 UI/UX expert) will work on a new Android app in a to-be-announced theme.

Hackathon weekend

The "V Hack Android" Netherlands hackathon will be held in the weekend of Friday 14th - Sunday 16th of September.

Preliminary schedule (subject to change)

Friday

19:00 - 21:30 Opening scrum with drinks & snacks

Saturday

10:00 Opening hackathon day 1

13:00 Lunch

18:00 Dinner

22:00 End

Sunday

10:00 Opening hackathon day 2

13:00 Lunch

16:00 Code freeze (Main area open to public / press)

16:30 Demo's and votes

17:30 Announcement of winners / results

18:30 End

The winning Dutch team will be chosen on Sunday. After this weekend the winning team can request support of the whole Dutch Android community to improve their app!

Win a trip to the final hackathon in London

The winning Dutch team will win a trip to the final hackathon in London, to be held in the weekend of Friday 26th - Sunday 28th of October, right after droidcon London. There the teams from various countries will continue to polish and improve their apps from which one winning team will finally be chosen. Again, support from the whole Dutch community is allowed, so let's help the winning team where we can!

Contend or attend

Please RSVP yes if you are planning on contending or simply want to attend the kick-off or help us out during the weekend. If you are contending also send us an e-mail at [masked] introducing your team -- including a team name and a tagline -- and we'll update this page with team info. If you are an independent Android developer or UI/UX expert and would like to participate please let us know via [masked] as well. We can introduce you to others who are planning to participate solo and build teams from that introduction. If you have any questions or comments on this event don't hesitate to contact one of the organizers or send us an e-mail at [masked].

Help spread the word

If you yourself are not interested, but know a good (team of) Android expert(s), born for challenges like this please make them aware of this event by sharing this event's meetup page.

Help us find sponsors

The entree fee of €50,- is purely to cover the costs for the location and food & drinks during this 3-day event. The first prize is sending the winning team to London. To finance this prize we need to attract some sponsors. If your company would like to sponsor this event send an e-mail to Wiebe and he can send your company some more information on the various sponsoring possibilities.

Parking & public transportation info

If you are coming by car you can drive by the BounceSpace building on the Weteringschans 28 and drop off your stuff (if you have a lot). Unfortunately no parking spaces are available at the BounceSpace building. Some parking suggestions are described here. If you come with public transportation you can use 9292.nl to plan your trip.

We hope to welcome a lot of teams on the Dutch version of the "V Hack Android" hackathon in September!

Kind regards,

Wiebe, Dennis, Arno, Hilbrand and Johan.

Team info

Team "Wasabi"

Hugo Visser (developer) Zenilja (developer) Gregor Doornbosch (designer) Team "Apps R Us"

Raul Portales (developer) Ronald van der Lingen (developer) Ron Jones (designer) Lone gunners...

In other words, people still looking for a team...

Iulia Stana (developer) Hans van der Scheer (developer) Fabio Tiriticco (developer) Daan van Berkel(developer) Arno den Hond (developer) Dennis Geurts (developer) <strong style="font-size : large">Local Gold Sponsors

Egeniq Itude mobile Luminis Global Silver Sponsors

Alcatel One Touch Sony Internet TV powered by Google TV Local Silver Sponsors

droidconNL VX Company

Next week we will kick off the "V Hack Android" hackathon in style... The "V Hack Android" opening event on Friday (with drinks and snacks) will be open to all and free! This is a great opportunity to meet the contending teams and talk Android with other DutchAUG-ers present.

We currently have four development teams competing in the "V Hack Android" hackathon next week, but... We've got room for more and there is still time to register as a solo developer or designer (or even better, a full team!).

We hope to see many of you on Friday, for the opening night, and the rest of the weekend to compete!

Kind regards,

Wiebe, Arno, Dennis, Hilbrand and Johan

We are very excited about droidconNL 2012, the largest Android conference in The Netherlands which is happening on 22/23 November in Amsterdam.

name: The Android NFC Meetup
description:
<em style="font-size : small">When you put two Android phones with NFC (Near Field Communication) capabilities close to each other... real close... in some apps a “Touch to Beam” dialog pops out and you can start sending pictures, or contact details, or whatever the programmers have come up with. NFC is an interesting way to communicate and which the latest Android devices are bringing to the masses. In this meetup we want to focus on what NFC is, what it’s future potential is and how you can use the “Touch to Beam” API in your own Android app and create whole new experiences for your end-users.

<em style="font-size : small">(P.S. help us get some attention for this meetup by adding above image as your Google+ cover photo!)

The Meetup Location: High Tech Campus

We are very pleased to announce that the meetup will take place on the "High Tech Campus" and we thank Philips for sponsoring this location for the meetup! Parking is free in one of the seven parking places. When you have parked your car you walk between many innovative company's buildings and research labs toward The Strip. The meetup will be held in Room "Lorentz-Zeeman" in the The Strip Conference Center.

The Meetup Agenda

16:30 Walk-in with drinks

17:00 Opening and Welcome

17:10-17:50 "NFC and Android: The Future Is Near" Martijn Coenen (Google)

NFC is rapidly taking off in mobile devices: more than 1 million NFC-capable Android devices are activated every week. There is an amazing opportunity for developers and entrepreneurs to build innovative, exciting and even futuristic applications using NFC. This talk is about why right now is the time to dive in, and how to use the simple but powerful Android NFC APIs to get it done.

Martijn is a Google software engineer working as the tech lead of the Android NFC (Near Field Communication) project. According to Martijn Android NFC currently leads the way in bringing NFC to mobile devices. Martijn is living together with his wife in the San Francisco Bay Area since 2011.

Follow Martijn on Google+

17:50-19:00 Dinner & NFC Hands-On

Some of you who have attended droidconNL 2012 last month know we had a small game running (with some serious prices). The game was called "The NFC Hunt" where people tried to tag as much NFC cards and tags as they could find. We still have a couple of those writable NFC cards lefts and we are going to hand them out for you to work on some code challenges during the meetup. Are you game?

19:00-19:40 "The Future Of NFC" Alexander Rensink (NXP)

* NFC explained
* Market status of NFC in mobile
* Remaining challenges in mobile
* NFC beyond mobile

Alexander is working as marketing director on Identification technologies and applications at NXP Semiconductors. NXP provides High Performance Mixed Signal and Standard Product solutions that leverage its leading RF, Analog, Power Management, Interface, Security and Digital Processing expertise. These innovations are used in a wide range of automotive, identification, wireless infrastructure, lighting, industrial, mobile, consumer and computing applications. A global semiconductor company with operations in more than 25 countries, NXP posted revenue of $4.2 billion in 2011.

19:40-20:20 "Using NFC to gain secure access to a building” Danny Mestriner (Tass)

Within the Chimera Access Control System (ACS) project at TASS it is possible to grant users access to the TASS building. A user has to log in via desktop or mobile, after which he has to request access via a button. He is then granted or denied access. Requesting access can also happen via NFC. Passive NFC tags can be implemented at the doors, so that when they are scanned, the app is started and (if the user is already logged in) the request is automatically sent. This eases the use of having to request access manually every time you enter the building.

Danny just graduated and started working at TASS from November 1, 2012. Having a thing for new technologies and the open-source characteristic of Android his interest for NFC was also piqued. He was put on the ACS project at TASS almost immediately from the beginning and worked with a team to add NFC functionality to it. In his spare time Danny likes to DJ.

20:20-20:30 Coffee Break

20:30-21:10 “NFC Interactions” Hendrik van der Linde - (Nedap)

Although NFC is seen primarily as a means to transfer information, it is a great way to interact with software as well. By using NFC as a means to make software more easy to use, users can focus on the important aspects of their job. In the case of Nedap healthcare this results in more time for giving care.

Hendrik van der Linde is one of the product owners at Nedap healthcare. He works on the phone applications used by home care nurses. Hendrik van der Linde is a skilled Java professional with a broad experience.

21:10-21:30 Drinks & Networking

Time to say hello to old Android friends and meet new, while drinking a cold beer or another refreshment.

 

This meetup has been made possible with the help from:
how_to_find_us: The meetup will be held in Room "Lorentz-Zeeman"

name: Android Code Puzzlers + Tips & Tricks Meetup
description:
The Android Code Puzzlers (+Tips & Tricks) Meetup

Sometimes you're stuck... Either you are doing something wrong, or the Android Framework is... (probably the latter ;-). It's sometimes hard to find the right, or simply a good solution to program challenges you face every day. In this meetup we want to train these skills by presenting you with some simple to really challenging Android Code Puzzlers to real-life Android programming situations. At the end of the evening you will be a more savvy Android programmer with a few new tricks up your sleeve ;-)

Example puzzles

Example 1 (2 points): "Name 5 different ways to handle a button click in an Activity."

Example 2 (5 points): "When I scroll to the top of the bottom of my ListView I see a blue vagueness popping in and out. How can you turn this off?"

Example 3 (10 points): "You create and execute an AsyncTask within the doInBackground method from another AsyncTask... Great solution, right? Or maybe not so great... What happens and why? How could you solve this?"

We will present many of these kind of puzzlers which you will solve in small teams. When you register for this meetup we ask you for you Android programming skill level (beginner / intermediate / expert), this to create equally levelled teams. Good answers will score some points for your team, which at the end of the evening might result in some well earned prizes, but more importantly, eternal fame.

Note: If you have a interesting code challenge which suits this meetup fine please send it to [masked] (Thanks in advance!)

Tips & Tricks

In the second half of this meetup we want to present you with our tips and tricks in how to setup an Android project, create project resources, present you with useful libraries, frameworks and tools we use to implement certain features in our Android apps. In return we would like to hear what you are doing to solve various day to day tasks in assembling your Android app and creating the best user experience for your users. Tips & tricks from us to you and you to us ;-). And open discussion to learn from each other and improve our Android apps!

The Agenda

16:30 Walk-in 17:00 Opening and Welcome (Michael Wolf - Luminis) 17:10 DutchAUG announcements (Dennis) 17:30 Android Code Puzzlers 18:30 Dinner 19:30 Android Tips & Tricks 20:30 Drinks and time to meet! Win stuff

We will be giving away a print version of O'Reilly's "Android Cookbook" and Wrox's "Android Application Development Cookbook" plus two Manning eBooks (of your choice) at this meetup. We will also be giving away a free ticket (value €140,-) to mdevcon 2013 to one of the meetup attendees!

We hope to get a full-house on this one, so don't wait to register soon!

Kind regards,

Your organizers: Wiebe, Dennis and Johan.

P.S. We ask for a small fee for this meetup to help us paying for pizza & drinks.

This meetup is made possible by Luminis

name: DutchAUG @ mdevcon 2013
description:
Like last year we will attend mdevcon 2013. And we are happy to announce that two DutchAUGers will be speaking at mdevcon 2013. Wiebe Elsinga will talk about Building Apps for Google TV and Paul Lammertsma will tell you all about how easy it is to use Custom Components in Android.

Where droidconNL is focussed on Android mdevcon opens the doors a little wider and welcomes developers working in the mobile industry in general. This year mdevcon is a two day event with a tutorial day on day 1, March 14th (Note: This is in the RAI Elicium, not in the Tuschinski Theater!) and a conference day on day 2, March 15th. Read all about the schedule here. If you are attending the conference day as well please RSVP yes here, so we can meetup on the conference day!

Please note: This conference is not free. RSVP-ing here does not allow you a free pass into mdevcon 2013. If you want to attend you can buy your ticket here.

About mdevcon

The conference is by mobile developers, for mobile developers. We have two days with multiple tracks, designed in such a way that whether you’re an android, iOS or other mobile platform developer, there’s always at least one session that should be of interest. The schedule contains many industry expert and can be found here. The venue is epic, it’s the 1920′s classic Tuschinski Theater in Amsterdam. We expect around 275 attendees.

Target audience
Mdevcon is targeted at developers working with mobile technology. There will be talks targeted at a specific platform and talks of a more platform independent nature. We welcome independent developers, freelancers and developers working for a company – It doesn’t matter who you are or where you work, if you work with mobile technology you’ll enjoy this conference.

March 14th "Tutorial day" in RAI Elicium

March 15th "Conference day" in Tuschinski Theater

name: Android Design Meetup
description:
Android Design Meetup

If you ever wonder what makes a good Android Design, what are the guidelines or how to go about making your Android application look awesome?

Then we (the Dutch Android User Group and Appsterdam) would like to invite you to the Android Design Meetup.

 

Keynote - Marie Schweiz (Novoda)

We are delighted to have Marie Schweiz join us via a hangout to give us a keynote.

Marie is a freelance Mobile/Android Visual & UX designer.

Marie's Website: marie-schweiz.de/

 

 

 

 

Design Matters - User Interface Design for Android - Suzanne Wensveen (UNITiD)

The second presentation of the evening is given by Suzanne Wensveen. She is going to take us on a journey to designing an Android application. It begins with defining the goal and preconditions and ends with the delivery to the developers.

Suzanne Wensveen is an Interaction Designer at UNITiD. UNITiD is a Design Agency that creates designs for digital applications that are useful, usable and meaningful to people.

She is also the creator of AndroidPatterns.com.

 

"Android design patterns" - Raul Portales (Platty Soft)

The consistency on Android UI and its patterns is one of the challenges of working with the platform. To help with this, Google created the Android Design Site explaining how things should be. But the UI components are only available on newer versions of Android... What to do???

In our last presentation Raul will present the main UI paradigms that Google is pushing forward and discuss them.

Raul is an entrepreneur who focuses on Android. He has over 5 years of experience in mobile development. He landed in Amsterdam to work at Hyves, Nowadays he works on his own apps and games as well as freelancing for other Dutch startups such as Layar or Fashiolista.

Raul's Twitter: https://twitter.com/sla_shalafi

 

Finally we have reserved some time for general design discussions.

You can ask the audience what they think about your application design, discuss the sliding menu or share ideas, experiences or thoughts about other aspects of Android design related topics.

 

The Agenda

17:00 Walk-in 17:20 Opening and Welcome 17:40 Keynote Marie + surprise guest 18:20 Design Matters - User Interface Design for Android 19:10 Dinner 19:40 Android design patterns 20:40 Open Space 21:30 Drinks and time to meet!  

We hope you can join us, so don't wait and register now!

Kind regards,

Your organizers: Johan, Hugo, Dennis, and Wiebe.

P.S. We ask for a small fee for this meetup to help us paying for food & drinks.

 

This meetup is made possible by DutchAUG and Appsterdam

name: Android Workshop for Beginners
description:
Hi there,

We are happy to announce an Android Workshop for Beginners. Beginners in Android that is. You need an intermediate level in Java or general Object Oriented (OO) programming to get the most out of this workshop. Don't be afraid to join if you are lacking in this area, we'll help you out before or during the workshop.

We will begin with a general presentation on Android architecture and key concepts. Then it's up to you to walk through a series of four labs (on your own laptop) to reach the goal of creating a complete Android app. There will be a couple of experienced Android developers walking around to answer your questions or help you out when you get stuck. We will give you some hints and tips on useful Android tools and you'll get the change to win print books or e-books and other swag.

Important notice: You can RSVP here, but you have to buy a ticket via the official Appril workshop page! The entry fee for this workshop is €30 and includes coffee / tea, drinks, snacks and pizza.

The schedule:

16.30: Walk-in with coffee / thee, drinks and snacks.
17:00: Presentation Android architecture and key concepts

17:30: Workshop lab1 & lab2
18.30: Pizza break

19.00: Workshop lab3 & lab4
20.30: Drinks & snacks

21:00: End

Prerequisites (important!)

To be prepared you need to install the following software and execute the Android Lab primer. This to simply test your Android development environment and because we cannot guarantee we have a good Wifi connection at the workshop location (and downloads can be several hundreds of megabytes). If you have any trouble or questions on any of the installations below let me know and we'll work it out together.

Java Development Kit (JDK) 6 (download)

You can develop Android apps in a couple of languages, but for most apps Java is the preferred language. You need a Java Development Kit (JDK) to develop Android apps. A Java Runtime Environment (JRE) is not sufficient.

Android Software Development Kit (Android SDK) - release 21 (download and install)

The Android Software Development Kit (SDK) is the base kit you need to be able to be able to build and package Android apps. Apart from the Android Framework (where you build your Android app against) the SDK provides you with a lot of tooling to run and test your app on your development system. For instance the SDK comes with an Android emulator which you can use to emulate all kinds of hardware. For the workshop you need to configure at least one Android Virtual Device (AVD), as these emulated devices are called, or you can simply develop apps on your own Android smartphone or tablet (and please, do bring them along!).

After downloading the Android SDK it is important that you at least install 1 Android platform (see "Adding Components"). For the workshop we use the latest platform (Jelly Bean 4.2.2 API 17) and maybe an old smartphone version (2.3.3) just in case, but the app should run fine on any platform, since we will be using the very basic stuff. Tip, also install the platform-tools, documentation, samples and the source code. These will come in handy when you want to know how Google has solved things in the framework itself.

Eclipse 4.2 (Juno) (download)

Eclipse is the Integrated Development Environment (IDE) which is best suited for Android development, and which we will be using for the workshop. Simply download the latest (4.2 a.k.a. Juno) Eclipse IDE for Java Developers and you are all set.

Eclipse Android Development Tools (ADT) plugin - release 21 (download and install)

This is a plugin for Eclipse which basically makes the Android tools from the Android SDK available in Eclipse and makes your job as Android developer a lot easier. We will spend some time on the tools available in the ADT plugin in the first exercise.

Test your setup

Finally we want to ask you to create a simple "Hello, world" Android project in Eclipse to test your setup. You can use the Android Lab primer, which is a shorter (and hopefully easier) write up of the "Build Your First App" tutorial by Google, but both should do the job. If you have a running "Hello, world" app you are all set for the workshop!

Final notes

The Android Workshop is aimed at intermediate Java developers with little to no Android knowledge. If you are lacking Java or general OO programming skills this workshop will be a real challenge. We still think it will give you a jump start if you really want to start Android development. A couple of experienced Android developers will be walking around if you have any questions during the workshop. Please bring all your Android devices, books and other cool stuff you would like to show off or use during the workshop. And if you won't be using them maybe your workshop neighbor is interested in using them during the workshop. This workshop is part of the Appril initiative. Hope to see you in Appril!

Johan Pelgrim

P.S. Yes, this is the same workshop we have given last year at Appril, so feel free to attend again, but you probably won't learn anything new ;-)

name: Android GCM Workshop
description:
Hi there,

We are happy to announce the Android GCM Workshop. You need a beginner/ intermediate level in Android to get the most out of this workshop.

We will begin with a general presentation that explains the prerequisites for using GCM. Then we introduce a REST API to an existing third party application server. If you want, you can design your own, if not this third party server is available throughout the course to communicate with. When communication to the third party server has been sorted out, you will start implementation of the Android GCM app.

Important notice: You can RSVP here, but you have to buy a ticket via the official Appril workshop page! The entry fee for this workshop is €30 and includes coffee / tea, drinks, snacks and pizza.

The schedule:

16.30: Walk-in with coffee / tea, drinks and snacks.
17:00: Presentation GCM prerequisites and API flow

17:30: Workshop third party REST API & Workshop Android GCM App implementation (1/2)
18.30: Pizza break

19.00: Workshop Android GCM App implementation 2/2
20.30: Drinks & snacks

21:00: End

Prerequisites (important!)

To be prepared you need to have the following software installed. As avid Android fan we assume that you already have this installed, but it can't hurt to remind you.

Java Development Kit (JDK) 6 (download)

You can develop Android apps in a couple of languages, but for most apps Java is the preferred language. You need a Java Development Kit (JDK) to develop Android apps. A Java Runtime Environment (JRE) is not sufficient.

The Android Software Development Kit (SDK) is the base kit you need to be able to be able to build and package Android apps. Apart from the Android Framework (where you build your Android app against) the SDK provides you with a lot of tooling to run and test your app on your development system. For instance the SDK comes with an Android emulator which you can use to emulate all kinds of hardware. For the workshop you need to configure at least one Android Virtual Device (AVD), as these emulated devices are called, or you can simply develop apps on your own Android smartphone or tablet (and please, do bring them along!).

After downloading the Android SDK it is important that you at least install 1 Android platform (see "Adding Components"). For the workshop we use the latest platform (Jelly Bean 4.2.2 API 17) and maybe an old smartphone version (2.3.3) just in case, but the app should run fine on any platform, since we will be using the very basic stuff. Tip, also install the platform-tools, documentation, samples and the source code. These will come in handy when you want to know how Google has solved things in the framework itself.

Eclipse 4.2 (Juno) (download)

Eclipse is the Integrated Development Environment (IDE) which is best suited for Android development, and which we will be using for the workshop. Simply download the latest (4.2 a.k.a. Juno) Eclipse IDE for Java Developers and you are all set.

Eclipse Android Development Tools (ADT) plugin - release 21 (download and install)

This is a plugin for Eclipse which basically makes the Android tools from the Android SDK available in Eclipse and makes your job as Android developer a lot easier. We will spend some time on the tools available in the ADT plugin in the first exercise.

Test your setup

Finally we want to ask you to create a simple "Hello World" Android project in Eclipse to test your setup. If you have a running "Hello World" app you are all set for the workshop!

Final notes

The Android GCM Workshop will only be fun if you bring your own Android device that is connected to the internet. We cannot guarantee we have a good Wifi connection at the workshop location. Please bring all your Android devices, books and other cool stuff you would like to show off or use during the workshop. And if you won't be using them maybe your workshop neighbor is interested in using them during the workshop. This workshop is part of the Appril initiative. Hope to see you in Appril!

Dennis Geurts & Johan Pelgrim
