description:
The Dutch Android User Group and the NOS, proudly brings you

Google I/O – Extended 2013 @ Hillywood.

Google I/O Extended lets you experience the magic and innovation of Google I/O remotely.
Part viewing experience and part community building, I/O Extended programming includes everything from live streaming the Google I/O keynote to meeting other DutchAUGers.

If you haven't got a ticket for the Amsterdam one, now is your chance and try to get a ticket for the Hilversum one.

The NOS have been so nice to supply us with a location and some food and drinks to make it a night to remember.

name: Google I/O 2013 Extended Amsterdam
description: The tickets are free but limited. Most probably the event is sold-out but some people may still cancel so I suggest you to keep an eye on http://gdgnl-io13.eventbrite.com/.

name: DutchAUG @ MDS
description:
Mobile Down South

On Friday June 7th 2013 MDS will be held in the beautiful High tech campus in Eindhoven (visit the website to get tickets).

MDS is a conference by developers, for developers working with mobile technology. There will be talks targeted at a specific platform and talks of a more platform independent nature.

Read more about the conference and schedule here.

 

DutchAUG @ events

DutchAUG will be present during the conference. And with our own organizers </a><a href="http://www.meetup.com/dutch-aug/members/9152200/">Johan Pelgrim and Hugo Visser giving a talk about "Android Code puzzlers & Tips + tricks" and Dennis Geurt on "GCM" it is a great opportunity to spread the word about the DutchAUG to the MDS audience.

If you are attending MDS as well let us know by RSVPing "Yes" to this meetup and maybe we'll meet up at one of the conference breaks or sessions.

name: Better builds
description:
Better builds

This meetup is about the tools you can use to use to further improve the quality of your app, and to streamline development of your apps.

We're very excited that we have two speakers that come to the Netherlands especially for this meetup!

We start of with Eric Lafortune from Belgium. Eric is the creator of Proguard and Dexguard.

Proguard is an Open Source tool for obfuscating (protecting), optimizing and shrinking Android apps, which is included in the Android SDK. If you don't know what this means, come to the meetup to learn from the creator of Proguard! If you do have experience with Proguard: this is your chance to ask Eric you all you want to know. Eric will present on what Proguard is and why it is an important tool for Android developers.

Our second guest is Christopher Orr from Germany. Christopher is the author of the Android- and Lint plugins for the Jenkins continuous integration engine. Topics of his talk will include an overview of Jenkins and what benifits building your Android applications using Jenkins + the Android plugin brings.

We will also have a "build clinic" this evening: having trouble with Proguard, setting up an Android project in Jenkins or just don't know where to start? Want to know how to add Proguard to your ant, maven or gradle project or how to run and it using Jenkins on multiple devices? Bring your app and ask the experts!

 

Agenda

Doors open at 17:00

17:30 Eric Lafortune

18:30 Diner

19:15 Christopher Orr

20:15 Break for drinks

20:30 Build clinic / Open discussion

21:30 End

 

Location

This meetup is hosted at the Qbus office in Amersfoort, which is only a 5-10 minutes walk from the Amersfoort train station. We recommend coming by public transport if possible.

If you come by car, please note that parking in the Groen van Prinstererlaan is for permit holders only, so don't park there. Instead, you can park on the separate private parking at the entrance located at the Barchman Wuytierslaan. Then walk around the building to the entrance at the Groen van Prinstererlaan.

name: Bier & Bitterballen
description:
We want to invite you to the "Bier & Bitterballen" meetup in café "Stairway to Heaven" in Utrecht to celebrate the start of a new DutchAUG meetup season in a more informal setting.

We supply the drinks and bitterballen, you bring your best stories! We hope to talk to a lot of you there!

 

Please inform us by a RSVP for this meetup so we can let the café know about our group size.

name: DutchAUG @ GDG DevFest Netherlands
description:
The GDG Dutch Android User Group and GDG Netherlands join forces in bringing you a single day event in the style of a true Google DevFest. This means interesting talks and hands-on labs, brought to you by national and international leaders using Google technology, in an informal setting, an inspirational environment with lots of room for open discussion and time to meet. 

Google Cloud, web and mobile technologies

We will bring you the latest in Google Cloud, web and mobile technologies like Android, App Engine, Angular.js, Chrome and more. (If you are an expert in any of Google's cloud, web or mobile technologies and would like to present on one of these topics let us know via the Call For Papers form for this event!)

Free entrance!

Entrance is free, but space is limited so please register soon! This meetup page is just a placeholder. You must book your ticket here (starting 10:00 AM)!

Updates on the program

Follow us on Google+ and Twitter for the latest news on this event!

GDG Dutch Android User Group: Google+, Twitter

GDG Netherlands: Google+

We hope to see you on Saturday October 19th!

name: DutchAUG @ Droidcon London
description:
On October 24th and 25th Droidcon London is happening again and we'll be there too! Droidcon London is 100% Android with great speakers and an excellent atmosphere.

Tickets are £200 if you register on or before August 30th, for more info and schedule see the Droidcon site http://uk.droidcon.com/2013/)

If you are attending Droidcon London as well let us know by RSVPing "Yes" to this meetup and maybe we'll meet up at one of the conference breaks or sessions.

name: Hackathon: "You Can Hack But You Can't Hide"
description:
<b style="font-size : 14px ; text-align : left">The Dutch Android User Group and droidconNL are happy to invite you to the coolest Android hackathon of 2013!

Are you a savvy Android developer or designer but have little time to play around with all the cool new Google Play APIs and Android features? Or are you lacking inspiration or quality time to think up the next generation Android apps? If you can’t hide your enthusiasm for Android and just enjoy building great Android apps this event is for you! 

Sign up and be inspired by your teammates and fellow contestants and measure your Android skills in a single day Android hackathon event, just before the biggest Android conference in The Netherlands, droidconNL!

"Location, location, location" The Android hackathon will be held on Sunday November 24th at the droidconNL 2013 venue; Science Park Amsterdam. We open the doors at 9am and explain the process and rules and start the hackathon a little after that. Then you have until 8pm to finish up your Android app and present it to a jury of Android experts. 

What's in it for me? Apart from quality time with your team mates and great prizes you’ll win eternal glory for winning the second DutchAUG hackathon and you can brag about your winning Android app for a whole year! At the end of the hackathon all contestant are invited to the “after-the-hack party” for an informal meet&greet with droidconNL speakers, sponsors and special guests.

How can I sign-up? You can sign-up at http://www.droidcon.nl starting Monday July 29th at 10 am sharp. We will allow 12 teams to register for this event so be sure to register sooner rather than later if you want to enter the competition. Note: RSVP-ing to this meetup.com event will not enter you in the competition. You must by a ticket via http://www.droidcon.nl!

Entrance: The entry fee for this competition is €25,- per person, which is used to cover some of the costs for lunch, dinner, drinks and snacks throughout the day. You can either sign-up as a solo Android developer or designer or sign-up with a complete team. The ideal team consist of two Android developers and one designer (the top teams from last year had two developers and a designer on board), but teams of three Android developers are allowed as well. We encourage Android development companies to register and sponsor their own team!

Further information: If you need further information about the hackathon or want to contact the organization about registering a company team or other sponsoring possibilities please send an e-mail to <a>[masked]</a>.
how_to_find_us: http://www.droidcon.nl/venue/

name: Hands-on with Android KitKat and Google Play Services
description:
So, we finally have KitKat in our hands with the new Nexus 5. Also Google Play Services is updated and has been split out in two versions, one for Froyo and the other for the newer devices. All we need now is a customer who will pay us to create an app which incorporates all of the great new features in both KitKat and Google Play Services so we can have some time to investigate these features. And then you wake up from your dream and realise time to investigate new stuff is something all developers lack, but love to do. 

In this meetup we want to challenge you to pick just one of the KitKat or Google Play Services features or APIs and do a little investigation, maybe a demo app, clean-up some code and do a short 10-15 minute presentation about your findings. If 10 to 12 people do this we end up with a meetup with a lot of experience, code and demo's to still have some kind of fulfilment about hacking away at all the cool new features to simply see if and how they work.

Are you game?

If you are excited about one of these features below (or another cool new feature not in the list) and want to do some investigation on how to set-up an Android project (preferably in Android Studio), create a demo and open source some code then please send us an e-mail at: [masked]. If you know a good Android developer who is working with one of these features already but doesn't know about our user group yet please encourage them to talk about their experience at this meetup.

The following topics and speakers have been confirmed:

Cloud Save - René de Groot
 René is lead Mobile developer at Sogeti and has done open source development of various applications, including the dev tool Device Profiler.

Backup Service - Quirijn Groot-Bleumink
Quirijn is a driven mobile software engineer and a keen traveller. He has already published multiple Android applications like IP Tools. Besides Android Quirijn has experience with web development and document management.

Printing Framework - Paul Lammertsma
Paul is CTO and co-founder of Pixplicity, Holland’s leading Android-specific consulting and app-building company. He applies his knowledge of Java, Android and Linux in Pixplicity to develop high-quality apps and provide technical solutions for customers such as Mercedes-Benz, Nestlé, De Telegraaf, AGIS and De Consumentenbond.

Achievements & Leaderboards - Raul Portales
Raul is passionate about developing apps with a great user experience. He has released several great games with Pill Tree in the past (a.o. Chalk Ball & Space Cat) and PlattySoft in the last couple of years (a.o Codemon).

Storage Access Framework - Hugo Visser
Our very own co-organizer Hugo is stepping up to the plate to talk on the new Storage Access Framework. Hugo is working on many Android apps at Qbus (a.o. Figure Running and Weerplaza) and has a couple of personal apps in the app store as well. His most popular app being Rainy Days.

Full screen Immersive mode & Screen Recording - Ali Derbane
Ali is a long time Android developer working at Itude Mobile. He is passionate about Android and spreading the word by hosting workshops and speaking at various conferences. His last talk was on functional testing using Calabash at both droidcon UK and NL (slides).

Activity Recognition - Jaap Beetstra
Jaap is an Android developer and co-owner at App It Up. App It Up created several Android apps, most related to automotive segment. Kenteken Opzoeken and DirectLease TankService are the best known.

GCM Cloud Connextion Server (XMPP) - Wolfram Rittmeyer
Wolfram is a Java (EE) software developer from Münster (Germany) who started focussing on Android development from 2010 onwards. He is well known for his great Android blog posts and -tutorials which you can find at http://www.grokkingandroid.com

Transition Framework - Bolot Kerimbaev
Bolot is a software engineer and instructor at Big Nerd Ranch. Bolot studied Computer Science at Georgia Tech, receiving both his B.S. and M.S. Degrees - while also teaching Taido Karate. Bolot has been developing web applications for over 14 years using Smalltalk, ColdFusion, Java, and even his own web server.

What's new in location + Geofencing - Bas Flaton
Bas is lead Android developer at Nspyre and is working in agile teams on large-scale Android projects, mostly running in non-phone environments (in-car, embedded).

Real-time multiplayer - Jaap-Jan Pruijs
Jaap has a background as a Java EE application architect (ABN-AMRO, Aegon, Transavia). With an interest in mobile technology since J2ME and games (winner of the 2012 gametechnology student challenge). He also likes to party and is currently developing the Android app for ravepas.nl.

We hope to see a lot of you at our first meetup in 2014!
how_to_find_us: There's a Q-Park Parking Garage beneath the Nspyre building. You'll get a free exit ticket during the meetup!

name: Dutch Android Open Space
description:
If you are familiar with Open Space meetups you know how valuable these type of meetups can be. It is very open, highly active and interactive. Always aiming to discuss, distill and find solutions for the most interesting topics, latest information and challenges which you are facing every day, in your role as Android professional. Seats are limited, so join sooner rather than later!

Theme: "Together we can build awesome apps!"

If you are working on mobile projects you know that time-to-market is often short. The client wants to have the best looking app and your end-users deserve the best user experience. How do you create an awesome Android app in such a short time frame and still keep smiling? How can we work together? What have you learned along the way and what is still a big hurdle to take, every time you start an Android project? Do you re-use components? And how do you build, test and deploy your app? All fair questions and hopefully disclosing the Open Space theme before the meetup will get you more excited to join the conversation.

Skills in our group...

All kind of roles and skills are represented in our group. From entrepreneurs to testers, graphics designers to architects and of course a fair amount of developers. We need each other to build better apps and this need is clearer than ever in our every day challenge to meet the deadline on some Android project and creating awesome user experiences while we are at it.

Process

We open the doors around 4:30pm and aim to start at 5:00pm with the opening, welcome, general announcement. After that we will explain the chosen Open Space process:

We will have a large board with empty time slots. Everybody will have a chance to write down a topic of interest in one of these time slots. (Of course, nothing holds you back to already think about or even prepare a topic you would like to see discussed). If we have more topics than time slots we will either open an extra breakout room, or simply vote on which topics we want to cover. After that we breakout in 30 minute sessions to discuss the top-voted topics. One person, per group, is asked to present what was discussed and possibly some answers, best practices or results. We repeat the breakout / plenary presentation bit two or three times.

(Tentative) schedule

16:30 Walk-in

17:00 Opening and welcome

17:15 Start Open Space

17:30 First Breakout Round

18:15 Dinner

19:00 Second Breakout Round

19:45 Break

20:00 Third Breakout Round

20:45 Drinks and time to meet.

This is what people said about our last Open Space meetup in 2012

"Excellent setting. Sessions were great and folks attending were really good. Everyone was able to learn something new and discussions were fun and constructive"

"Good spirit. Enthousiastic people. A lot of questions and answers. The place to be and meet Android lovers."

"I love open space meetings. Was a bit sceptical that an open space meeting this short could work but apparently an evening is plenty of time to get some great discussions going"

We hope to see a lot of familiar but also new faces at this meetup, so if you have never come to a DutchAUG meetup before, now might be a good time ;-)

Kind regards,

 

Wiebe, Dennis, Hugo and Johan.

name: Hands-on with Chromecast
description:
Yes!!! We've got hold of several Chromecasts! In this meetup we simply want to get our hands dirty and discover what is needed to write small apps which cast video, audio or custom content to Chromecast devices.

We want to split out in groups of 3 to 4 developers and hack away with a real Chromecast device, hooked up on a TV or monitor. At the end of the evening we'll organize a show and tell to see what the teams have come up with. The team with the winning concept, with preferably a live demo, will win a Chromecast device for every team member!

Note: You don't need to have a Chromecast publish account yourself, nor do you have to register any of the devices we use in this meetup. We've prepared this for you.

The schedule:

17:00 Dinner
18:00 Demo & setup development environment
18:30 The "hands-on" part
21:00 Show and tell + drinks

Some useful links to get started:
Google Cast SDK
Google Cast Developer's Guide
Android API
Android Sender App Development
Google Cast Examples on Github
Google Cast G+ Community

This meetup is hosted and sponsored by Sogeti.

name: Appril Android Beginners Workshop
description:
Hi there,

We are happy to announce a new edition of the Android Beginners Workshop. You need an intermediate level in Java or general Object Oriented (OO) programming to get the most out of this workshop. Don't be afraid to join if you are lacking in this area, we'll help you out before or during the workshop.

We will begin with a general presentation on Android architecture and key concepts. After that we present you with 5 lessons, which we'll introduce with a short technical presentation on what you will learn and do yourself in the lesson exercises. There will be a couple of experienced Android developers walking around to answer your questions or help you out when you get stuck. We will give you some hints and tips on useful Android tools and you'll get the change to win print books or e-books and other swag.

Important notice: You can RSVP here, but you have to buy a ticket via the official Appril workshop page! The entry fee for this workshop is €30 and includes coffee / tea, drinks, snacks and pizza.

The schedule:

• 16.30: Walk-in with coffee / thee, drinks and snacks

• 17:00: Presentation Android architecture and key concepts

• 17:30: Lesson 1

• 18:00: Lesson 2

• 18.30: Pizza break

• 19.00: Lesson 3

• 19:30: Lesson 4

• 20:00: Lesson 5

• 20.30: Drinks & snacks

• 21:00: End

Prerequisites (important!)

To be prepared you need to install the following software. If you have any trouble or questions on any of the installations below let <a>me</a> know and we'll work it out together.

Git client (download)

Please install a Git (GUI) client or command line tools. You need to checkout the sample projects to be able to do the exercises in this workshop. Sourcetree is a pretty good (and free) GUI client.

Java Development Kit (JDK) 6 (Mac) or 7 (Windows/Linux) (download)

You can develop Android apps in a couple of languages, but for most apps Java is the preferred language. You need a Java Development Kit (JDK) to develop Android apps. A Java Runtime Environment (JRE) is not sufficient.

Android Studio Bundle (install)

Android Studio is the de facto standard IDE for building Android apps these days. This bundle (for Windows, Mac and Linux) includes:

• Android Studio early access preview

• All the Android SDK Tools to design, test, debug, and profile your app

• The latest Android platform to compile your app

• The latest Android system image to run your app in the emulator

For the workshop you need to configure at least one Android Virtual Device (AVD), or you can simply develop apps and deploy them on your own Android smartphone or tablet (and please, do bring them along!). If you are running Windows you might need to install the correct device driver for your phone.

After you have installed Android Studio please check for updates (in the "Android Studio" menu item on a Mac or the "File" menu on Windows/Linux) and upgrade to the latest version (e.g. v0.5.2 end of March).

What you will learn

• Working with Android Studio and using Gradle for building your Android project
• Building and running Android apps on your own device or Android Virtual Device (AVD).
• Basic understanding of resources and resource qualifiers
• Working with Activities, and get basic understanding of the Activity Lifecycle
• Learn about common Views and how to add them to an Activity
• Learn how to interact with these views in your code.
• Learn how to listen to (click) events.
• Basic understanding of tasks and the activity back stack
• Move from one Activity to another with explicit and implicit Intents
• Basic understanding of ListViews and Adapters
• Working with the ArrayAdapter
• Creating String Array resources
• Extending the BaseAdapter to create a custom adapter
• Creating more complex layouts for the list items
• Basic understanding of Fragments and the Fragment lifecycle
• Basic understanding of ViewPagers and the FragmentPagerAdapter
• Playing sounds with the MediaPlayer

Final notes

The Android Workshop is aimed at intermediate Java developers with little to no Android knowledge. If you are lacking Java or general OO programming skills this workshop will be a bit of a challenge. It will give you a jump start, if you really want to start Android development, but you might find the general Java or OO concepts a little challenging. A couple of experienced Android developers will be walking around if you have any questions about Android, Java, or OO programming during the workshop.

Please bring all your Android devices, books and other cool stuff you would like to show off or use during the workshop. And if you won't be using them maybe your workshop neighbour is interested in using them during the workshop.

This workshop is part of the Appril initiative. Hope to see you in Appril!

Johan Pelgrim

name: Appril Workshop iBeacons & Android
description:
In this workshop we will cover Bluetooth Low Energy. It's required that you bring your own Android device that supports the new Bluetooth Low Energy stack (Android 4.3 and up, Bluetooth 4.0). First we will explain Bluetooth Low Energy and its abilities. We will also explain how to discover and identify individual iBeacons.

After that, we will proceed with the Gatt Profile. You will learn how to inspect various Gatt Services and how to read Characteristics. During the course of this workshop we will make sure that there are plenty BLE devices available on site to experiment with.

Experienced Android developers are present to help you with the exercises or answer any questions you might have about Android/ BLE. Coffee / tea, sodas, snacks and a pasta or pizza dinner are included in the price.

- - - - - - - - - -

Important notice: You can RSVP here, but you have to buy a ticket via the official Appril workshop page! The entry fee for this workshop is €30 and includes coffee / tea, drinks, snacks and pizza.

name: Android Code Puzzlers II
description:
Android Code Puzzlers II

If you have been to our previous Android Code Puzzlers meetup last year you know what this meetup is all about: Learn more about our everyday Android coding challenges, quirks in the Android framework, fun facts, great discussions, tips & tricks and winning great prizes.

In this meetup you will compete in teams in trying to solve many code challenges, puzzels, general Android questions. To gain knowledge, win prizes, but most of all learn from each other and have fun!

Note: If you have a interesting code challenge which suits this meetup fine please send it to [masked] (Thanks in advance!)

Example 1 (2 points): "Name 5 different ways to handle a button click in an Activity."

Example 2 (5+5 points): "When I scroll to the top of the bottom of my ListView I see a glow that indicates I've reached the boundary. How can you turn this off? How can you customize it?"

Example 3 (5 points): "You create and execute an AsyncTask within the doInBackground() method from another AsyncTask... Great solution, right? Or maybe not so great... What happens and why? How could you solve this?"

The Agenda

16:30 Walk-in
17:00 Opening and Welcome
17:10 First wave of questions and challenges
18:00 Dinner
19:00 Second wave of questions and challenges
20:30 Drinks and time to meet!

Win stuff

We will give away a couple of Chromecasts, exclusive Android swag, books and more for the best performing teams. Stay tuned for an update on the prize details.

Kind regards,

Your organizers: Wiebe, Dennis, Hugo and Johan.

 

This meetup is made possible by Nspyre

</a>

<a href="http://www.meetup.com/dutch-aug/events/100986442/"http:/www.nspyre.nl/mobile">
how_to_find_us: Nspyre is located inside the large Conclusion building next to Stadium Galgenwaard. The entrance to the building is on the stadium side, from the square.

name: Google I/O 2014
description: For the lucky few who got a ticket to Google I/O 2014 let's use this meetup page to find each other, keep each other up-to-date on which external events and parties you are joining and meetup in San Francisco!

name: Google I/O Extended 2014 @ NOS (Hilversum)
description:
In the heart of the Media Park in Hilversum, you're invited to watch Google I/O 2014 live on the NOS' big projection screen!

The Dutch Android User Group and the NOS and proud to host

Google I/O Extended 2014 @ Hillywood

We won't just watch the keynote—there will be lightning talks and of course plenty of community building. With food and drinks compliments of NOS, join the fantastic Dutch community of developers for an evening to remember!

There are only 60 seats available, so don't hesitate and register quickly before all seats are taken.  

Agenda

17:00    Introduction and dinner
17:20    NOS on New Media
17:40    Dutch AUG on What to Expect
18:00    Google I/O 2014 Keynote
20:00    Dutch AUG on Coming Soon
20:40    See you next time!

Getting there

The NOS is well accessible by train to station Hilversum Noord. When you arrive at the Media Park, you can find their building here:

• Travel to NS-station Hilversum Noord.
• From the platform, take the overpass to enter directly into the Media Park. You'll be on a square where you'll see among other buildings, the Mediacentrum.
• Follow the green pedestrian signs for "Hoofdroute" ("Main route") and "MAX Studio 23". This will lead you to the right of the Mediacentrum, across a gravel path and down some stairs.
• At the bottom of the stairs, continue following the green pedestrian signs for "NOS-gebouw" ("NOS building"). Proceed under the building in front of you, and turn right.
• After about 200 meters, the NOS building is on your left side. The big stone stairs leads to the revolving door.
• Report at the reception.

By car

Be sure to reserve a guest parking spot. We'll try to make sure everybody arriving by car has free parking at the NOS. This form closes Tuesday afternoon, after which you may be stuck paying for parking.

name: Google I/O Extended Extended BBQ
description:
Overwhelmed by the new APIs announced at Google I/O?
So are we.

The Dutch Android User Group is hosting the <strong style="font-size : medium ; text-align : center">Google I/O Extended Extended BBQ so we can share experiences with those shiny new things.

Haven't had the time? No worries. Lightning talks on various topics will get you up to speed in short 15 minute talks.

As usual, there will be plenty of community building. With food and drinks compliments of Pixplicity, join the fantastic Dutch community of developers for a fun event and fantastic BBQ!

There are only 40 seats available, so don't wait! Register quickly before they're all are taken.

Johan and Dennis are taking along their fancy new Android Wear watches and less fancy, but a lot of fun, cardboards. It will likely be your first opportunity to play hands-on with the Samsung Gear Live!

If you're ever interested in giving a session, please don't hesitate to contact an organizer! We'd love to have you.

Agenda

17:30     Doors open
18:00    Welcome & Announcements
18:15      Johan Pelgrim & Dennis Geurts: Google I/O recap
18:30     Maarten Edgar: Working with Material UI
 18:45     Ali Derbane: Android Wear
19:00    Break 
19:15      Mark van der Tol: Android Wear
19:30     Leo Agtereek: Android L: Fragmentation
19:45     Wolfram Rittmeyer: New Views
 20:00   BBQ!
 21:30     See you next time!

Getting there

Pixplicity is very close to Utrecht Centraal and is well accessible by public transportation:

• Google Maps is very accurate for planning your trip!
    - Busses arrive from the central train station very regularly: 1, 47, 64, 66, 74, 77, 81, 160, 361 and 377 in the directions of Houten, Nieuwegein, Vianen or Gorinchem. Be sure to check which side of the station it departs from! The walk to the office from Europaplein or Socrateslaan is about 7 minutes. 
    - Trams ST and 260 from the central train station stop at Kanaleneiland Zuid every 5 to 10 minutes, as well as bus 63 to Vianen. The walk to the office from here is about 13 minutes. 
• Look for the Pixplicity sign outside building B1. 
• Take the stairs or the elevator to the second floor.

For an overview of travel options, please see Pixplicity's route map: https://mapsengine.google.com/map/edit?mid=z2nglA2o73Ec.kNFuzsLMtOYY

By car

Parking is free at Pixplicity and there should be plenty of spots. Please park behind the building facing the fence. You'll find Pixplicity in building B1.

name: Hands-on with Android Wear
description:
What's all this hype about wearables?

In this workshop, we'll get our hands dirty with the Android Wear SDK. No doubt that you've seen the LG G Watch, Samsung Gear Live and Motorola Moto 360, so surely you're excited to play with them! Dive into creating an Android Wear app, and learn how you can adapt your app to appear on these cool new devices!

Please note: it's required that you bring your own Android device running Android 4.3 or higher. Not sure if your device supports Android Wear? Check: http://g.co/WearCheck on your device to find out. If you cannot bring an Android Wear compatible device, check with a buddy that you can team up using his or hers.

Please note: Some experience with Android is required. If you're familiar with setting up a project in Android Studio and building an app with notifications, you're ready to start working with Android Wear. Please install the latest Android SDK tools, platform-tools, build-tools and Android 4.4W (API 20) SDK at home, to avoid download-mania on-site!

During the course of this workshop we will make sure that there are plenty Android Wear devices available on site to develop and test with.

This is a guided workshop with prearranged material. Experienced Android developers are present to help you with the exercises or answer any questions you might have.

Free entrance, dinner, drinks, and a lot of fun!
how_to_find_us: http://www.hogeschoolrotterdam.nl/hogeschool/locaties/wijnhaven-107

name: GDG DevFest The Netherlands 2014
description:
The GDG Dutch Android User Group and GDG Netherlands join forces in bringing you a single day event in the style of a true Google DevFest. This means interesting talks and hands-on labs, brought to you by national and international leaders in using Google technologies. In an informal setting and inspirational environment, there is lots of room for open discussion and time to meet.

Best of all: it's completely free!

Google Cloud, web and mobile technologies

We will bring you the latest in Google Cloud, web and mobile technologies, including Android Wear and Android L, App Engine, Angular.js, Polymer, Go and much more.

If you are an expert in any of Google's cloud, web or mobile technologies and would like to present on one of these topics let us know via the Call For Papers form for this event!

Free entrance!

Entrance is free, but space is limited so please register soon! This meetup page is just a placeholder.

You must book your ticket through Eventbrite here! 
 (registration starts at 10:00am on Monday September 1st)

https://www.eventbrite.com/custombutton?eid=12711296831

Updates on the program

Follow us on the Google+ event page and Twitter for the latest news on this event!

name: Android Fundamentals Study Groups
description:
</a>

<a href="http://www.googledevelopersstudyjams.com/">

This February and March we will kick-off 2 Android Fundamentals Study Groups in the Google Developers Study Jams initiative. 

If you are serious about Android and have passed the various introductory material this study group is for you! 

You will work through Udacity's Android Fundamentals curriculum at your own pace and will meet your peers weekly to discuss progress, work with each other through the curriculum and work on your final project. 

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LfVBFFoy9Y0

We expect you to spend around 6 hours per week to work through the Udacity course material before the on-site meetup. During the weekly study group evenings you will receive support about that weeks lesson by a DutchAUG facilitator on-site who has already done the course and/or has already passed certification.

The locations: The study groups will meet in two locations. Frank Bouwens will lead the study group at the Hogeschool Rotterdam and Hugo Visser and Johan Pelgrim will lead an on-line study group via Hangouts on Air and support the Rotterdam study group where needed.

The Schedule:

The on-line study group will kick off on Tuesday February 3rd and will meet weekly from 6:30pm to 7:30pm

The Rotterdam Study Group will kick off on Wednesday February 4th and will meet weekly from 6:30pm to 8:30pm

Following Udacity's course outline we will discuss the following lessons in the following time frames.

Feb 1-7:     Lesson 1

Feb 8-14:  Lesson 2

Feb 15-21: Lesson 3

Feb 22-28: Vacation / Catch-Up (no meetup)

March 1-7: Lesson 4a

March 8-14: Lesson 4b

March 15-21: Lesson 5

March 22-28: Lesson 6

We will finish off the study group program with a final project sprint session on Saturday March 28th.

Prerequisites: This is an advanced course intended for students with at least 3 years of programming experience in Java (Udacity's Intro to Java is a helpful background if you're looking to refresh your Java skills) or another object-oriented programming language (for example: C++, Objective C or Python) and preferably 1 year of programming experience in Android. Here is some more info of what you'll learn in the Developing Android Apps course.

Entry fee: €25,- (€12,50 if you are a student or take part in the on-line study group) To host 7 study group evenings and a final project sprint session with drinks, snacks, etc. costs money. We are a foundation, so we don't have to make a profit, but we do want to break even. Secondly, to meet each other weekly for two months is a serious commitment. By charging money we want to make sure people who are attending are serious about learning how to create better quality Android apps. 

Note: Attending this course does not directly result in official Udacity certification! If you want to pass the official Android Fundamentals certification you normally must buy a subscription. However, free certification for some attendees is possible, pending your course performance. So do well on the course, attend every session, help others, build a great final project and maybe you will be eligible to get certified for free!

If you want to go ahead and start with setting up your development environment and get access to the lessons please sign up here.

More info soon!

name: We are living in a Material World
description:
We are living in a Material World.

You must have heard and read lot about Material Design that Google introduced at Google I/O 2014 but are you already implementing it in your apps?

Google's vision: "Create a visual language for users that synthesizes the classic principles of good design with the innovation and possibility of technology and science. This is material design".

This meetup will help you bring Material Design to your app(s). Two designers and two developers will explain the impact that Material Design will have, and show you some real life examples.

The Agenda

16:30 Walk-in
17:00 Opening and Welcome
17:10 Multiplatform Design
18:00 Dinner
19:00 Case: How to go from iOS to Android Material Design
19:40 Coffee break
20:00 Material design & implementation
20:40 Drinks and time to meet!

Kind regards,

Your organizers: Dennis, Paul Hugo, Johan and Wiebe.

This meetup is made possible by Nspyre
how_to_find_us: Nspyre is located inside the large Conclusion building next to Stadium Galgenwaard. The entrance to the building is on the stadium side, from the square.

name: Dutch Android Open Space 2015
description:
If you are familiar with Open Space meetups you know how valuable these type of meetups can be. It is very open, highly active and interactive. Always aiming to discuss, distill and find solutions for the most interesting topics, latest information and challenges which you are facing every day, in your role as Android professional. Seats are limited, so join sooner rather than later!

Skills in our group...

All kind of roles and skills are represented in our group. From entrepreneurs to testers, graphics designers to architects and of course a fair amount of developers. We need each other to build better apps and this need is clearer than ever in our every day challenge to meet the deadline on some Android project and creating awesome user experiences while we are at it.

Process

We open the doors around 4:30pm and aim to start at 5:00pm with the opening, welcome, general announcement. After that we will explain the chosen Open Space process:

• We will have a large board with empty time slots.
• Everybody will have a chance to write down a topic of interest in one of these time slots. (Of course, nothing holds you back to already think about or even prepare a topic you would like to see discussed!)
• If we have more topics than time slots we will either open an extra breakout room, or simply vote on which topics we want to cover.
• After that, we breakout in 30 minute sessions to discuss the top-voted topics in which. One person, per group, is asked to present what was discussed and possibly some answers, best practices or results. We repeat the breakout / plenary presentation bit two or three times.

(Tentative) schedule

16:30 Walk-in

17:00 Opening and welcome

17:15 Start Open Space

17:30 First Breakout Round

18:15 Dinner

19:00 Second Breakout Round

19:45 Break

20:00 Third Breakout Round

20:45 Drinks and time to meet.

This is what people said about Dutch Android Open Space 2012

"Excellent setting. Sessions were great and folks attending were really good. Everyone was able to learn something new and discussions were fun and constructive"

"Good spirit. Enthusiastic people. A lot of questions and answers. The place to be and meet Android lovers."

"I love open space meetings. Was a bit skeptical that an open space meeting this short could work but apparently an evening is plenty of time to get some great discussions going"

We hope to see a lot of familiar but also new faces at this meetup, so if you have never come to a DutchAUG meetup before, now is a great opportunity! ;-)

Kind regards,
Paul, Wiebe, Dennis, Hugo and Johan

name: Hack-and-Fly hackathon
description:
Start to Hack in Amsterdam or Paris and finish in San Francisco!

Don’t forget your luggage! If you’re the Grand prize winner you’ll be going straight to San Francisco.

In the beginning of June we are partnering up with BeMyApp and Schiphol Airport who are organising a two day Hack-and-Fly hackathon. This is a perfect opportunity to bring all your skills and passion to good use and make a change in the aviation industry. Hack-and-Fly is the first-ever airport Hackathon simultaneously hosted by Amsterdam Schiphol Airport and Paris-Charles de Gaulle Airport from June 5th-7th. 

The goal of this event is to look for local talent and creativity to help improve the airport experience, satisfy air travellers' needs and to create personalised solutions. Both airports are also interested in carrying on some of the projects and ideas after the event, with necessary data provided to support the development. You can register here. 

Heads up! There's a pre Hack-and-Fly hackathon workshop at Schiphol on May 21st 7PM. The flight and baggage data will be presented there. More info on http://hackandfly.com 

Special request: We are still looking for volunteers for this event. If you can help out during the day to give teams (technical) support or if you think you should be on the jury to pick a winner on Sunday, or have any other questions let us know, or contact Sandra Lee from BeMyApp directly via e-mail or give her a call at <a>[masked]</a>.

Note: Registration for this event is only possible at http://hackandfly.com. You can RSVP here, but that does not entitle you entrance to this event! Please use this event page to get in touch with other Daugians who are going and maybe team up!

name: Hack away for a day!
description:
You are a hard working Daugian. Putting a lot of love and diligence in the Android apps for your clients during the week, but you never have the time to explore new things. New github libraries, new hardware, updated tutorials and trainings on d.android.com. If this is you, then boy if this meetup isn't just what you need to sharpen your toolbelt!

Hack away for a day

On Saturday June 20th the Dutch AUG to coming together in the specially created co-working space of Elements Interactive in Almere. We'll bring the espresso's and cappuccino's, the drinks, lunch, various Android devices and other cool hardware like Glass, Chromecasts, UriBeacons, ADT-1's, Nexus Players and whatever the boys are bringing back home from Google I/O. All for you to hack away with! We'll also be doing walk-in presentations in another room throughout the day. Simply attend whichever workshops or presentations you'd like and get hacking away for the rest of the day.

The co-working space is open from 10:00am - 5:00pm

Lunch is somewhere between 12:00pm and 1:00pm, but of course you are free to simply grab a sandwich and continue coding!

11:30am Chromecast kick start (Hugo)

2:00pm Demo by Elements Interactive 
2:30pm TBD

3:30pm Google I/O Report
4:00pm Drinks and snacks + Lightning talks and demo's
5:00pm End

P.S. If you want to take part in the Android Beginners Workshop please let Johan know so he can send you some preparation instructions up front.

name: Android & Gradle… A great match!
description:
Join us for two great talks on Gradle! Have a bite to eat, a drink to sip, great conversation with your peers, sharpen your Gradle skills and boost your Android build process along the way!

17:30 Doors open

18:00 Dinner

18:45 "Gradle, the why and how" (Mr. Haki)
We are going to take a step back and look a bit into the history of Gradle. Why was it developed, what makes it different compared to other build tools? We are going to learn about the basic principles of Gradle and how Gradle tries to be a great build tool. We look at core concepts of Gradle with small examples.

Mr. Haki has written a couple of books on Gradle and also writes regularly about Groovy, Grails and Gradle on his blog.

19:30 Coffee Break

19:45 "Extending Gradle… Development. Distribution. Rock!"  (Vitalik Zasadnyy)
Have you ever had a task to automate builds with Gradle? When working on a big project build scripts can become messy very easy. Luckily for us, Gradle makes it easy to decouple build logic from the configuration. During the talk, we'll talk about extending gradle, developing and publishing plugins and check what Gradle APIs available for that. This presentation will be interesting for developers who want to dig deeper into Gradle, rather than just using the Android plugin, as well as build masters that author build logic on a regular basis and want to learn best practices for organizing build code, plugin development and writing custom extensions for Gradle.

20:30 Drinks & snacks

21:00 Doors closed

We're co-organizing this meetup with the brand new Gradle-Meetup group. So if you want to continue focussing on Gradle now's a good time to join that meetup group as well ;-)

This meetup is hosted by

The Dutch Android User Group is sponsored by

description:
We're super excited to invite you to our next meetup, which is all about Kotlin!

We've invited Svetlana Isakova from the Kotlin team at JetBrains to get you up-to-speed with the language. We've asked her to focus her talk on Android development specifically and why now is a pretty good time to start using Kotlin to be a more productive Android developer. We're very much looking forward to this meetup and we hope to see a lot of you there!

[Lightning talks of max 10 minutes by the community]

[A panel of experts will answer your questions or respond to statements presented by the moderator]

We have a couple of lightning talks lined up, but if you have experimented with Kotlin, or even better are currently using it in production code let us know in your RSVP and we'll line you up in the "Kotlin from the trenches" section of the evening.

name: Hack away for a day: The Firebase Edition
description:
On Saturday January 21st we are meeting up at TQ for a new edition of Hack away for a day. This time our focus will be Firebase! Apart from a great Firebase t-shirt the best Firebase hack project team (of max 3 people) will be rewarded with a great Android Things kit including a RPI 3 + a Rainbow Hat!

Do you have any questions regarding Firebase, have you played around with Firebase or do you have something really cool that you made Firebase? Come join us and show and tell!

Firebase Google Developer Expert Stefan Hogendoorn will also join the party and give a presentation on Firebase. If there's anyone you can ask a question about Firebase, it's him!

"An Introduction to Firebase" (Stefan Hogendoorn)
For some Firebase is part of the daily activities, for some Firebase is new. In today's introduction we'll do a  quick overview of 'What is Firebase' and how to build cool applications. What to look out for when modelling your data, how to implement authentication and everybody's favourite subject: The business of your application.

Even if you're not familiar with Firebase this is the best place and time where you can go through the Udacity course Firebase in a weekend. Johan and Jairzinno wil do a quick overview of what you'll learn in this course and how easy it is to integrate Firebase in their talk "Firebase in 25 minutes"

TQ will provide an awesome working space. We'll bring the drinks, lunch and snacks so you can focus on hacking away the whole day. 

The co-working space is open from 10:00am - 5:00pm. 

Lunch is somewhere between 12:00pm and 1:00pm, but of course you are free to simply grab a sandwich and continue coding!

The schedule (under construction)

9:30am    Doors open
10:00am Opening and welcome
10:15am  Idea pitch and team forming 

10:30am START HACKING
                 "An Introduction to Firebase" Stefan
"Firebase in 25 minutes"Johan and Jairzinno
5:00pm  END HACKING
                 Drinks and snacks
                 Lightning talks and demo's
6:00pm  Winner announcement + Closing words

Pro tip: Join our Slack group (invite code DAUG) and team up with other Daugians before the meetup!

name: Hash Code 2017
description:
On Thursday February 23th you can sharpen your coding skills by teaming up with others, choose a programming language and solve whatever programming challenge you will be presented with by Google. Sounds like a fun challenge? It is. The assignments from last year and a test assignment are available to find out to sharpen your skills for the qualification round.

Note: There's no specific Android coding skills required. If your go-to language is Go or Scala, Java, Ruby or Groovy you can enter this competition. Tip: Pick a language where it is easy to process input files and produce output files.

Help us spread the word by informing your colleagues, class mates or teacher about this challenge.

More information and registration at http://g.co/hashcode

Update Monday February 20th:

If you haven't done so already, you must register via https://hashcode.withgoogle.com to be able to receive the problem statements and send in your solution output.

Furthermore, to be able to show up on the Minor Programmeren hub dashboard you must connect your team to our hub (last setting on the team page). You can do this in the judge system at https://hashcodejudge.withgoogle.com

Example:

If you haven't created a team yet don't worry. We'll hook you up with a Minor Programeren hub team on site this Thursday!

In the mean time, here are some programming puzzle websites to sharpen your skills.

Tip: Already create some sort of little framework to read and process input files. For pretty much all sections in the problem statement you get an input file which you must process and upload the result in the judge system.

Pro tip: take a look at past problem statements to be fully prepared!

See you this Thursday!

Your organizers

name: Tinker away with Android Things & Philips Hue
description:
On Thursday March 30th we are opening the doors of the Q42 office in The Hague to welcome you to another hands-on Android meetup. This time we'll be tinkering away with Raspberry PI 3's with RainbowHats running Android Things and various Philips Hue lights. We'll have two great talks and plenty of support walking around to get you up-to-speed in no time.

Thanks to Pimoroni we've got 5 RainbowHats to give away for the best teams! If you can't wait to play around with Android Things the RainbowHat buy one here. 

If you want to be eligible to win a RainbowHat you must team-up (before or during the meetup). Teams consist of 2 to 4 people. You need to bring your own laptop and if possible bring your own RPI 3 with a clean flash of the latest Android Things developer preview image. (If necessary we'll use the give away RainbowHats during this meetup). We'll have plenty of Philips Hue lights and bridges, but again, if you prefer bringing your own hardware feel free to bring them along. The prizes will be given to the best team project demo at the end of the evening.

Agenda (under construction)

16:00 Doors open for the early birds.

Feel free to come in a little early, grab a Raspberry PI 3 running Android Things or Philips Hue bridge and light to get some extra time on your hack project.

17:30 Dinner

18:00 Bootstrapping Philips Hue (Christiaan Hees - Q42)

Christiaan works at Q42 on the Philips Hue platform. He'll give an introduction on how to use the local Hue api to turn on your connected lights with a couple lines of code.

18:20 Bootstrapping Android Things (Dennis Geurts - Luminis)

Dennis works as IT Architect at Luminis Arnhem and has worked with on various IoT and Android projects. Keeping an eye on the Brillo and Weave technologies at the time Dennis is now keen on working with Android Things in his hobby and work projects and will help you bootstrap your Android Things project in his talk.

18:40 Project pitching, team-up and start hacking

21:30 Drinks + project demo and prize winner announcements

This meetup is sponsored by Q42

----

Final info:

If you come by car you can park in Parking Garage Laakhaven near the Q42 office (approximately €4,- per hour before 5:30pm and €8,- for the whole evening, after 5:30pm). The Q42 office is right next to the Den Haag HS train station, so public transportation is a good alternative to paying parking fares.

If you are planning to work with the Rainbowhats tomorrow take a look at this example weatherstation project on Github. It'll give you a good head start to get going quickly.

If you are planning to work with the Philips Hue lights take a look at the getting started page. Note: You need a Philips Hue developer account to be able to view the tools and SDK pages.

Keep an eye out on the discussion on the meetup page. If anything else comes up we will post it as a comment there.

See you tomorrow!

Your organizers.

name: Clean—Kotlin—Mockito
description:
Join us for a diverse set of presentations from the Dutch Android community!

Agenda

18:00   Dinner

We will be exploring the reasons why we adopted Kotlin, our expectations going in, our practical findings along the way, and the impact on our way of coding and the impact on the team.

19:00   Moving forward, evolving our architecture - Kilian Steenman & Thomas Middel
Describing the way our projects evolved over time, from GodActivities to clean architecture. The pitfalls and benefits.

19:30  Break

19:40   Testing made sweet with a Mockito - Jeroen Mols
Thanks to many tools and libraries, writing unit tests is a breeze! So all your apps currently have >80% code coverage, right? Yay! Or wait... is it really? Is all your common logic (networking, databases,...) tested? Do you isolate parts of your code base to keep your tests small? And what about providing relevant testing data?

20:30   Drinks & networking

21:00    Doors closed

This meetup is sponsored by M2mobi.

Update on public transportation and parking facilities nearby (In Dutch only unfortunately. If you need tips in English give Johan a ping): 

Bezoekersinformatie M2mobi

Ons adres is Herengracht 266, 1016 BV te Amsterdam. De ingang vind je twee deuren naar links van de ingang van Wieden+Kennedy.

Let op: we hebben een intercom aan de rechterkant van onze voordeur. Je kunt daar aanbellen, waarna we de deur op afstand voor je kunnen openen.Hetzelfde voor de glazen deur die je in de hal vindt. Ons kantoor bevindt zich op de vierde verdieping, aan de linkerkant als je de lift uitkomt.Voor onze exacte locatie en/of een persoonlijke routebeschrijving, zie Google Maps 

Vervoer

De makkelijkste manier om ons kantoor te bereiken is op de fiets of met openbaar vervoer. Voor onze deur vind je verschillende fiets-parkeerplaatsen. Daarnaast hebben we op drie minuten lopen tramhalte “Westermarkt”, waar de tramlijnen 13, 14 en 17 stoppen. Ook de tramhalte “Dam” is slechts vijf minuten te voet, waar tram 1, 2 en 5 stoppen.

Het centrum van Amsterdam kan per auto soms lastig te bereiken zijn. Hetzelfde geldt voor het vinden van een parkeerplaats. Er zijn bij ons voor de deur de nodige parkeerplaatsen, maar die zijn zeer gewild en dus bezet. Wil je geen risico lopen op vertraging en eindeloos ronddwalen, dan raden we je aan te parkeren in de Q-Park (‘Europarking’) op de Marnixstraat 250. Vanaf de parkeergarage is het zo’n tien minuten naar ons kantoor lopen. Geef het door aan je contactpersoon bij M2mobi als je hier je auto hebt staan.

Een alternatief is Q-Park (‘De Bijenkorf’) op het Beursplein 15 of op de Elandsgracht aan de straat. Vanaf daar is ons kantoor ook een kleine 10 minuten te voet. 

Voor verdere vragen en/of wijzigingen, graag contact opnemen met Frederiek Beck (office  manager / HR, op[masked] of per email naar [masked]).

name: Architectures & Tools @ ING
description:
Join us for an evening with sessions and discussions about architectures and tools. Always wanted to know what other developers use when they develop their apps? Or how they’ve set their app up? On this evening we’ll cover both. We’ll have 3 sessions about architectures and an hour of open mic stage where everyone can share their architecture and tools.

Sessions 
Remco Mokveld, Android developer @ The Capitals 
Remco will present a newapproach to application architecture which is much more heavily focussed on the features of an app rather than how those are implemented. Remco will describe the benefits of this approach compared to what we previously did and give a short example of how he implemented this.

Jordy Langen, Team Lead Mobile development @ Mediaan 
Working with a relatively new technology means there is always much to be gained and improved. Now that we fixed our problems with views, networking and asynchronous processing it’s time to put that all together and build an architecture on top of this.

There is the MVP and although even Google is using it nowadays, it’s not perfect. Jordy will talk about how they implemented MVP in their latest apps, which problems they faced and how they worked around them. Jordy thinks Model View Intent is a natural evolution of MVP and it might just be the next best thing.

Ronald Warners, Chapter Lead Android @ ING 
The ING Mobile Banking app had its 5th birthday. Ronald will tell us about what happened when developing the Mobile Banking app. Which design and architectural decisions were made in the past and which ones are being made now?

Serj Lotutovici, Senior Android Developer @ Travelbird
A good architecture is more than just a fancy structure of your project, or trendy thing that everyone has to follow. With so many great examples out there on how to build an MVP or MVI app, one might think that the job is done and there is nothing left to discover or create. But one burden of any architecture is that it has to scale with Android, and that is not an easy task.

In this small session we are going to dive deep into the challenges that one faces when adopting an architecture on an example of a complex RecyclerView that relies on an RxMVI approach.

Hugo Visser, Android Developer @ Little Robots
A quick tour of the new architecture component libraries, we're we'll look at what these components are and what they aim to solve

Program

name: Kotlin's here! @ Sogeti
description:
Many of us asked for it and finally it’s here! At this year’s Google I/O Kotlin was announced as a fully supported language for developing Android apps.

So let’s dig in! Let’s see what we can do with Kotlin.

Join us for talks about Kotlin in general and how we can use it for developing apps.

Rene de Groot - Everyday Kotlin
With domain languages, lamda's. coroutines, tail recursions, operator overloading  and (weird) JVM-annotations Kotlin might seem overwhelming. So lets take a look at everyday Android development and how Kotlin helps you there. We take a look on how your knowledge of Java and Java best practises puts in an advantage when programming in Kotlin.

Serj Lotutovici - Getting Schwifty: Functional Programming with Kotlin
Writing good software is hard, writing bug free software is next to impossible, but that doesn’t mean that we should never tend to that mythical abstract of `fun` and sustainable code. Add multithreading, state management and a pile of interconnected components to your system and you’ll find that functional programming is your best bet against the vicious spaghetti monster. So, let’s take off… our hats, and get schwifty with Kotlin.

Simon Vergauwen - Sealing in the flavor with Kotlin
Kotlin brings sealed classes and functional programming paradigms to the table. A type safe design can do miracles for your codebase so let's take a look how we can model runtime errors in our type system and what advantages FP concepts offer.

Program

name: Introducing ARCore
description:
After Ronald van der Lingen’s talk on what’s new in AR/VR at our Extended Extended meetup someone asked why Google wouldn’t release a SDK for AR without the required sensors for Tango. Apparently that question was spot on because not much later Google released ARCore. 

ARCore is a platform for building augmented reality apps on Android and is being offered as an early preview so that you can start experimenting with building new AR experiences.

Immediately Ronald started digging in the API’s and is more than happy to show us what it’s all about. So if you’re interested in what ARCore has to offer or just curious in AR in general this is the meetup for you.

name: Hash Code 2018
description:
Think you could come up with a way to optimize Internet coverage for Project Loon balloons? Or how about routing Google Street View cars through Paris?

Step into the shoes of a Google engineer and tackle these types of challenges during Hash Code, a team-based programming competition for students and professionals (18+) across Europe, the Middle East and Africa organized by Google. You pick your team and programming language, we pick a real-life engineering problem to solve. Are you up for the challenge?
The competition is divided into two stages:
* an Online Qualification Round on 1st March at 18:30 CET
For this round, your team can participate from wherever you’d like, including one of our Hash Code hubs. Hubs allow for teams in the same location (eg. city or university) to compete side-by-side in a more fun and exciting environment.
* a Final Round on 1st April
Top scoring teams from the Online Qualification Round will be invited to Google Paris to compete in the Final Round of the competition.

Find some teammates, sign up today at g.co/hashcode and we'll see you at the UvA!

Your organizers

name: Android's Media API landscape @ Blendle
description:
You probably use apps to watch videos or listen music on a daily basis. With both tools in the Android SDK as external libraries you can create your own feature rich video or audio app. But how complex is it?

This meetup, as you’ve guessed it, is all about media API’s on Android. Remco Mokveld will talk about how to deal with offline video in combination with ExoPlayer.

ExoPlayer is an open source project maintained by Google on Github to offer more features than Android’s standard MediaPlayer API. ExoPlayer is used by many apps on the Google PlayStore and is also a core part of YouTube’s app.

The second talk of the evening will shine some light on Media API's for Audio. Dion Segijn will talk about his experience setting up audio for Blendle’s latest product.

Parking your car might not be the easiest thing to do in this area so we advice to travel by public transport, the location is located very close to Amsterdam Central.

name: Bier & Bitterballen
description:
Come join us for another edition of the annual "Bier & Bitterballen (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bitterballen)" meetup at Quignon in Utrecht. We want to invite you to celebrate the end of another DutchAUG meetup season:
We supply the drinks and bitterballen, you bring your (Android) stories!

What will next year's theme be? Join us to liven up the discussion with drinks and snacks on us.

We hope to see to a lot of you there!
how_to_find_us: Along the Oudegracht and walking distance from Utrecht CS. The address is Oudegracht 134.

name: Machine Learning & Storage @ Disney
description:
Join us for our first meetup of 2019! We'll be heading to Disney Streaming Services where we'll cover Machine Learning and Android Storage APIs.

Sandra Dupré - Push Machine Learning into your apps: ML Kit and Tensorflow Lite
Machine Learning is not just a buzzword. Combine this technology and mobile development can become one of the greatest progress in mobile world. From Tensorflow to ML Kit, Google gives to us tools to push intelligence into our apps.
So, what’s really Machine Learning? What’s TensorFlow Lite? How powerful is ML Kit? This talk will give you the basics to start the Machine learning adventure on mobile.

Sjoerd van Gestel - The fragmented world of Android storage
This talk centers around my first hand experience with the fragmentation within Android related to creating a storage indicator for api 21 and up.

Schedule:

18:45 Opening talk + introduction Disney Streaming Services
19:00 Push Machine Learning into your apps: ML Kit and Tensorflow Lite by Sandra Dupré
19:45 break
20:00 The fragmented world of Android storage by Sjoerd van Gestel
20:30 Time for some drinks

name: Navigation Component & Zero Knowledge Proof @ ABN AMRO
description:
Join us for our first meetup at ABN AMRO. Former DutchAUG organizer Hugo Visser will talk about the Navigation Component and Bakhtar Sobat will give a presentation about Zero Knowledge Proof.

Navigation Component by Hugo Visser
Hugo will talk about the ins and out of the Navigation Component.

Zero Knowledge Proof by Bakhtar Sobat
Are you willing to share your biometric identification with someone else? Thanks to Zero Knowledge Proof(ZKP) you don’t have to. With ZKP you can convince about your identity without sharing it.
